articles.title: The Best Time to Retune Your Career? It’s Probably Right Now
articles.content: January is the big month for buying gym memberships. The excesses of the holiday season leave many of us looking to make improvements in our lives — a search that often leads straight to the elliptical machine.

articles.title: ‘Apprentice’ Returns, and December Jobs Data Are on the Way
articles.content: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

articles.title: Google Helping Mobile Publishing? Some Publishers Are Not So Sure
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Last month, Federico Viticci, who runs MacStories, a news site devoted to Apple and its products, made a change in how the site publishes articles for mobile gadgets. MacStories, he declared, would no longer support a Google-backed method for faster loading of mobile web pages, called AMP.

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 2
articles.content: The United States Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. The three- and six-month bill auctions have also been rescheduled for Tuesday.

articles.title: In Year of Anti-Muslim Vitriol, Brands Promote Inclusion
articles.content: The gentle piano music starts as the doorbell chimes. A white-haired Christian pastor greets his friend, a Muslim imam, and the two converse and laugh over a cup of tea, wincing about their creaky knees as they prepare to part ways. Later, it spurs the same idea in each for a gift: kneepads sent via Amazon Prime. (It is a commercial, after all.)

articles.title: What U.S. Tech Giants Face in Europe in 2017
articles.content: For American tech behemoths like Google and Facebook, Europe can be both a blessing and a curse.

articles.title: For Non-Tech Companies, if You Can’t Build It, Buy a Start-Up
articles.content: For years, mergers and acquisitions in technology were fairly straightforward: Every investment bank kept a list of a dozen or so companies like Google and IBM that had a track record of acquisitions and cash to deploy. When the time and price were right, bankers would seek to match the tech giants with a start-up, and a deal would be hatched.

articles.title: Airlines, Now More Proactive on Weather, Allow Fliers to Shift Own Travel Plans
articles.content: A few days before his flight home to Seattle from Tokyo in October, Bruce Ryan learned that a windstorm might disrupt air travel in the Pacific Northwest.

articles.title: A Turntable Reborn Turns Its Back on Its Hip-Hop Legacy
articles.content: UTSUNOMIYA, Japan — In the sofa-appointed listening room of a factory north of Tokyo, hi-fi fans can listen to vintage vinyl records on a sound system costing $45,000, including a sleek silver turntable. Musical choices include rock — the Eagles’ “Hotel California,” sounding warm and vivid through four-foot-tall speakers — jazz and classical.

articles.title: Growing a Different Apple
articles.content: At Apple, Brian Latimer was in charge of protecting some of the company’s deepest secrets.

articles.title: Where to Go if You Forget Your Hotmail Password
articles.content: Q. I forgot the password to my Hotmail Live account and I don’t have the same phone number as I did when I set it up. What should I do to regain my Hotmail account?

articles.title: Anshu Jain to Join Cantor Fitzgerald as President
articles.content: Anshu Jain, who was forced to step down from the top job at Deutsche Bank after a series of regulatory mishaps, will join the private trading firm Cantor Fitzgerald this month as group president.

articles.title: With Trump, an Economic Feast With Surprises on the Menu
articles.content: Ladies and gentlemen, please, please take your seats. It is time again for our annual DealBook closing dinner, where we look back at the year that was to toast and roast the year’s deal makers and look ahead to what may come next.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: The Year Ahead, Anshu Jain Joins Cantor
articles.content: Happy New Year, DealBook readers.

articles.title: Historic Designation Sets Stage for a Washington Market District’s Future
articles.content: WASHINGTON — At the Florida Avenue Market, the restaurants and neighborhood groceries of the nation’s capital found what they needed to satisfy their customers for decades. The main building and gritty collection of wholesale-food warehouses sold meats, vegetables and cheeses to buyers large and small.

articles.title: S.E.C.’s In-House Judges Face Supreme Court Scrutiny
articles.content: Sometimes an obscure provision of the Constitution becomes the focal point of a significant controversy that requires the Supreme Court to straighten things out.

articles.title: A Threat to U.S. Democracy: Political Dysfunction
articles.content: Is American democracy broken?

articles.title: How to Automatically Label New Gmail Messages
articles.content: Q. In the web browser, is there a way to automatically assign one of my Gmail labels to incoming messages from specific people?

articles.title: Even Before He Takes Office, Trump Knocks Automakers on Their Heels
articles.content: DETROIT — Donald J. Trump has promised to change the way American automakers do business. Less than three weeks before his inauguration as president, he has already knocked the companies on their heels.

articles.title: Megyn Kelly’s Jump to NBC From Fox News Will Test Her, and the Networks
articles.content: For Megyn Kelly, the shift from Fox News to NBC — where she will host a daily daytime show and a Sunday newsmagazine program — will be a test of whether she can connect with a broader audience in a different format and reach another level of television stardom.

articles.title: Anthony B. Atkinson, Economist Who Pioneered Study of Inequality, Dies at 72
articles.content: LONDON — Anthony B. Atkinson, an acclaimed British economist who pioneered the study of changes in the distribution of wealth and income, allowing for a better understanding of poverty and inequality, died on Sunday in Oxford, England. He was 72.

articles.title: Daily Report: An Ex-Apple Employee Firm, Far From the Tree
articles.content: Can a company be successful like Apple, without being Apple to the core?

articles.title: Hulu Adds CBS to Its Coming TV Streaming Service
articles.content: Hulu, one of several companies vying to create a lower-cost alternative to cable bundles, will include CBS when its streaming television service is unveiled this year, the company announced on Wednesday.

articles.title: Fed Officials See Faster Economic Growth Under Trump, but No Boom
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials expect Donald J. Trump’s election to result in somewhat faster economic growth over the next several years, but they see little chance of the boom Mr. Trump has promised, according to an account of the Fed’s most recent meeting in mid-December.

articles.title: Chase Sapphire Reserve Card’s Huge Bonus Will Be Slashed
articles.content: When a Wall Street banking institution starts throwing 100,000-point bonuses at credit card customers, it may be best to grab them before they inevitably disappear. And so it goes with Chase Sapphire Reserve, a card that the bank, JPMorgan Chase, introduced last summer. The bank offered a sign-up bonus worth $1,500 to people who spent $4,000 on the card in the first three months they had it and then redeemed the bonus for travel.

articles.title: The Sketch Guy’s Most Valued Lessons Still Sting. How About Yours?
articles.content: One day, I imagined that I had a vault where I kept the most valuable lessons of my life. I opened it and was surprised to find it full of my most painful experiences.

articles.title: Start-Ups Hope Couples Say ‘I Do’ to Online Wedding Planning
articles.content: Planning a wedding remains a largely traditional pursuit. For many couples, it is a frustrating monthslong project that requires sifting through masses of details and costs on venues, services and products. Now, a variety of start-ups are trying to cut down on that information overload by harnessing new technologies to capture a slice of a multibillion-dollar industry — what some have called the wedding-industrial complex.

articles.title: Coming to Carnival Cruises: A Wearable Medallion That Records Your Every Whim
articles.content: DORAL, Fla. — Inside a clandestine Carnival Corporation complex here, two former Disney executives have been plotting a drastic cruise industry overhaul.

articles.title: What to Know About CES 2017
articles.content: To average people, the name of the International CES, formerly known as the International Consumer Electronics Show — one of the largest tech conventions, taking place in Las Vegas this week — will seem dated, if not highly misleading.

articles.title: Mario Isn’t the Only Classic to Leap to Mobile
articles.content: UNLESS you live under a mushroom, you are likely to know that one of the biggest computer gaming events last year was the arrival of Nintendo’s Super Mario Run on iPhones and iPads. While versions of the game have been available for consoles for years, Mario had never made the leap to non-Nintendo devices before now.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Shifts Ahead of a Trump Administration, Bitcoin Soars
articles.content: New year, new administration and, soon, a new chairman for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

articles.title: Bitcoin Price Soars, Fueled by Speculation and Global Currency Turmoil
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The virtual currency Bitcoin has been swept up in yet another speculative frenzy, pushing its price toward the peak it last reached in late 2013.

articles.title: CES Q. & A.: Our Reporter on the Best Consumer Tech of 2017
articles.content: Tech reporter Brian X. Chen answered questions about what’s in store for consumer tech 2017.

articles.title: Record 2016 for U.S. Auto Industry; Long Road Back May Be at End
articles.content: DETROIT — Unexpectedly strong sales of new vehicles in the United States in December propelled the industry to another record figure in 2016: 17.55 million sold.

articles.title: A Higher Minimum Wage in 2017
articles.content: This year, 19 states took matters into their own hands and raised the minimum wage.

articles.title: The Kia Soul Exclaim Adds Pep to Its Boxy Figure
articles.content: IN 2009, when the Kia Soul was introduced, it was roundly criticized as a blatant copy of the square-shaped Scion xB. At the time, Toyota’s youth brand had sold an average of 46,000 xBs annually over six years to coveted younger buyers, a good reason for Kia to go to the square-shaped well.

articles.title: 2016’s Winning Investors Talk About 2017, and Donald Trump
articles.content: Last year was one of unusually big surprises for markets — none more so than the election of Donald Trump. Not only were many money managers and experts dead wrong about his chances, but they were doubly wrong in betting on a big market sell-off in the event he won.

articles.title: Rockefeller Foundation Picks Rajiv J. Shah, a Trustee, as President
articles.content: Rajiv J. Shah, a trustee of the Rockefeller Foundation, was asked about six months ago to join the committee that would select the foundation’s next president. He said no. Instead, Mr. Shah, who until recently had been the administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, ultimately said he wanted to be considered for the post.

articles.title: Amazon to Open Retail Store in Manhattan at Time Warner Center
articles.content: SEATTLE — Amazon is bringing one of its experiments in brick-and-mortar retailing to New York.

articles.title: Bringing iCloud Files Down to Earth
articles.content: Q. I want to download specific files from my iCloud account in order to have them physically on my laptop and delete them from iCloud. How do I do this?

articles.title: Macy’s Will Cut 10,000 Jobs After Poor Holiday Sales
articles.content: Struggling with sagging sales over another crucial holiday shopping season, Macy’s announced on Wednesday that it was eliminating more than 10,000 jobs as part of a continuing plan to cut costs and close 100 stores.

articles.title: Megyn Kelly Being Replaced by Tucker Carlson at Fox
articles.content: Tucker Carlson, the veteran cable television host and conservative writer, will succeed Megyn Kelly in the coveted 9 p.m. slot on Fox News, solidifying the network’s right-wing identity in prime time as it prepares to cover the administration of President-elect Donald J. Trump.

articles.title: Volkswagen Said to Be Close to Settling Justice Inquiry Into Emissions
articles.content: Volkswagen is nearing a deal to pay more than $2 billion to resolve a federal criminal investigation into its cheating on emissions tests, according to three people briefed on the negotiations.

articles.title: Frontier Airlines Is Said to Hire Banks to Plan Stock Debut
articles.content: Warren E. Buffett recently revealed a willingness to invest in airlines after years of shunning them, and ever since, those stocks have soared. Now, one more company is aiming to be added to the list of publicly traded airlines.

articles.title: A Settlement Highlights the Complexity of Credit Scores
articles.content: IN the latest skirmish in a protracted battle, federal regulators have settled charges with two major credit bureaus for marketing credit scores and related products in misleading ways.

articles.title: Where Trump Sees Economic ‘Disaster,’ Experts See Something More Complex
articles.content: President-elect Donald J. Trump has called the American economy a “disaster.” But in Sioux Falls, S.D., Scott Lawrence, a local businessman and Trump voter, has a different take.

articles.title: American Apparel Could Bolster Amazon’s Standing With Trump
articles.content: In the retail-store slump, Jeff Bezos may be holding a Trump card. Amazon.com, the e-commerce giant he runs, is considering a bid for the bankrupt American Apparel, according to a Reuters exclusive, just as Macy’s and other department stores are losing sales and cutting staff. A deal could be a handy way to show a president-elect suspicious of Silicon Valley that thousands of working-class jobs are being saved.

articles.title: In Sweden, Happiness in a Shorter Workday Can’t Overcome the Cost
articles.content: A controversial experiment with a six-hour workday in one of Sweden’s largest cities wrapped up this week with a cheerful conclusion: Shorter working hours make for happier, healthier and more productive employees.

articles.title: Changes Ahead for Conan O’Brien’s Late-Night Show on TBS
articles.content: Conan O’Brien’s late-night show may be going off the nightly grind.

articles.title: Department Stores, Once Anchors at Malls, Become Millstones
articles.content: For decades, a corner spot at the mall was a sure path to success for big American department stores like Macy’s. Not anymore.

articles.title: Daily Report: The Next Voice You Hear Will Be Amazon’s
articles.content: They say talk is cheap. In tech right now, it is also very valuable.

articles.title: How to Pounce on Best Credit Card Offers (Before Banks Pull Them)

articles.title: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Snoozing at CES
articles.content: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

articles.title: Russia Requires Apple and Google to Remove LinkedIn From Local App Stores
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Smartphone users in Russia can no longer download the LinkedIn app on iPhone or Android devices, following a similar move in China to block The New York Times app on iPhones.

articles.title: Dialysis Chains Receive Subpoenas Related to Premium Assistance
articles.content: The nation’s two largest dialysis chains, Fresenius and DaVita, said on Friday that they had received subpoenas from the Justice Department for information about their relationship to a charity that provides assistance paying the insurance premiums of needy patients.

articles.title: Nat Hentoff, Journalist and Social Commentator, Dies at 91
articles.content: Nat Hentoff, an author, journalist, jazz critic and civil libertarian who called himself a troublemaker and proved it with a shelf of books and a mountain of essays on free speech, wayward politics, elegant riffs and the sweet harmonies of the Constitution, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 9
articles.content: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

articles.title: Rick Ross Documentary Video Doubles as Ad for Checkers
articles.content: In an effort to give back to his hometown community in Florida, Carol City, the hip-hop star Rick Ross decided to fulfill a childhood dream: He bought a Checkers fast-food franchise.

articles.title: Santa Delivered the Drone. But Not the Safety and Skill to Fly Them.
articles.content: My dad got a drone for Christmas.My dad lost a drone on Christmas.

articles.title: Detroit Auto Show Reveals a Google-Designed Van That Could Steer the Industry

articles.title: Uber Extends an Olive Branch to Local Governments: Its Data
articles.content: The ride-hailing company Uber and local governments often do not play well together. Uber pays little heed to regulation while city officials scramble to keep up with the company’s rapid deployment and surging popularity.

articles.title: Sticker Shock, and Maybe Nausea, Hamper Sales of Virtual Reality Gear
articles.content: SEATTLE — For a technology to crack the mainstream, there is an unspoken understanding: It shouldn’t make the people who use it want to throw up.

articles.title: Wall Street Clearinghouse to Adopt Bitcoin Technology
articles.content: After months of talk and hype, the world’s biggest banks have taken the first steps toward moving a significant piece of financial infrastructure onto a so-called blockchain — the technology introduced to the world by the virtual currency Bitcoin.

articles.title: Takeda’s Bid for Cancer Drug Maker Looks Expensive
articles.content: Japanese companies’ overseas shopping sprees tend to be overpriced. Takeda Pharmaceutical is the latest acquirer to pay over the odds. Takeda, a $34 billion drug maker, is spending $5.2 billion, a 75 percent premium, for Ariad Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company with a middling cancer drug.

articles.title: Eurozone Jobless Figures and U.S. Bank Earnings Will Be Released
articles.content: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

articles.title: F.B.I. Arrests Volkswagen Executive on Conspiracy Charge in Emissions Scandal
articles.content: The F.B.I. has arrested a Volkswagen executive in Florida, accusing him of playing a central role in a broad conspiracy to keep United States regulators from discovering that diesel vehicles made by the company were programmed to cheat on emissions tests.

articles.title: UnitedHealth Group to Buy Outpatient Surgery Chain for $2.3 Billion
articles.content: UnitedHealth Group, one of the largest and most diversified health insurance companies in the United States, said on Monday that it planned to buy Surgical Care Affiliates, a chain of outpatient surgery centers, for about $2.3 billion. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2017.

articles.title: One Phone, Many Instagram Accounts
articles.content: Q. I have two different Instagram accounts. Is there a way to use both on my phone at the same time without constantly entering the name and password?

articles.title: Under New Chairman, S.E.C. Enforcer Role Might Shrink
articles.content: The announcement by President-elect Donald J. Trump that he will nominate Walter J. Clayton, a quintessential Wall Street deal lawyer, as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission raises questions about how securities laws will be enforced during the new administration.

articles.title: With Competition Fierce, Even Elite Law Firms Resort to the Unusual
articles.content: America’s law firms, even the most prominent, are mired in an era of noticeably modest growth and volatility in the industry, and 2017 promises to be no better.

articles.title: In Election Hacking, Julian Assange’s Years-Old Vision Becomes Reality

articles.title: Specialty Pharmacies Say Benefit Managers Are Squeezing Them Out
articles.content: From its storefront in Union City, N.J., Prime Aid Pharmacy caters to patients with a wide range of ailments, from rheumatoid arthritis to hepatitis C. The business prides itself on getting patients their necessary drugs, employs a staff that speaks 10 languages and delivers medications by car in New York and New Jersey.

articles.title: SoftBank’s $100 Billion Investment Fund Starts to Take Shape
articles.content: Many business titans have made the trek to Trump Tower for a private audience with Donald J. Trump since he was elected president, but none have made a bigger splash than Masayoshi Son, the billionaire telecommunications entrepreneur.

articles.title: How Valeant Had a Bright Idea but Took It Too Far
articles.content: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International’s failed strategy had a grain of sense at its center. Drug makers spend over $50 billion a year on research and development, but the payoff keeps declining. Valeant tried to address the problem by acquiring companies, slashing research outlays and jacking up prices to keep the top line growing. But its aggressive approach backfired.

articles.title: Clare Hollingworth, Reporter Who Broke News of World War II, Dies at 105
articles.content: From a single gust of wind, Clare Hollingworth reaped the journalistic scoop of the century.

articles.title: Chief Executive of Audio Firm Sonos Steps Down
articles.content: SEATTLE — Over the years, Sonos has weathered competition from better known rivals like Apple and Bose to find a devoted audience among audio enthusiasts. But lately its wireless speaker has lost ground to an unexpected competitor, Amazon’s Echo.

articles.title: HarperCollins Pulls Book by a Trump Pick After Plagiarism Report
articles.content: HarperCollins is withdrawing the digital edition of Monica Crowley’s 2012 book “What the (Bleep) Just Happened?” from retailers, after evidence of plagiarism.

articles.title: Volkswagen Set to Plead Guilty and to Pay U.S. $4.3 Billion in Deal
articles.content: Volkswagen is on the verge of pleading guilty to criminal charges and paying $4.3 billion in fines, in a deal that would resolve a federal criminal investigation into its cheating on vehicle emissions tests, the automaker said on Tuesday.

articles.title: Publishers Encounter Political Storms in Turn to Right
articles.content: Milo Yiannopoulos — the infamous internet troll, Donald J. Trump supporter and editor at Breitbart News — has compared Islam to cancer, mocked transgender people and suggested that women who are harassed online should stay off the web. Last July, he was permanently barred from Twitter for violating the platform’s rules against hate speech and harassment.

articles.title: Trinity Mirror in Talks to Acquire Stake in Tabloid Publisher

articles.title: Volkswagen Executive’s Trip to U.S. Allowed F.B.I. to Pounce
articles.content: When F.B.I. agents learned that a prime suspect in the Volkswagen emissions scandal was traveling to the United States, investigators knew they were on the cusp of a rare feat: the arrest of an overseas corporate executive accused of wrongdoing.

articles.title: Obama’s Work to Limit Mergers May Stop With Trump Administration
articles.content: WASHINGTON — A nascent effort by the Obama administration to limit corporate consolidation, begun after officials concluded that a lack of competition was hurting the American economy, appears to be coming to an abrupt end as the Trump administration takes charge.

articles.title: JPMorgan Ordered to Pay Damages for Firing Whistle-Blower
articles.content: JPMorgan Chase inappropriately retaliated against a former employee who raised questions about the bank’s sales tactics and investment products, the Labor Department found.

articles.title: Higher Minimum Wage May Have Losers
articles.content: CHICAGO — A growing number of economists have found that many cities and states have considerable room to raise the minimum wage before employers meaningfully cut back on hiring.

articles.title: Donald Trump’s News Session Starts War With and Within Media
articles.content: He deemed BuzzFeed News “a failing pile of garbage,” mocked an inquiry about his tax returns — “Gee, I’ve never heard that one before” — and, in an unheard-of moment for a presidential news conference, shouted down questions from a CNN reporter, declaring, with some menace, “Not you.”

articles.title: The Guide to Being an Airbnb Superhost
articles.content: IN my spare time, when not writing about consumer technology for The New York Times, I have a sideline renting out a cabin on Airbnb. So when Jose reserved the property last October, it was nothing unusual. He said he wanted to host some relatives for a quiet weekend in the mountains. I welcomed him without hesitation.

articles.title: Big Banks Lose Bid to Halt Crisis-Era Lawsuits

articles.title: A Financial Mystery Emerges. Its Name? Steven T. Mnuchin Inc.
articles.content: Steven T. Mnuchin plans to divest himself of his financial interests in 43 companies, hedge funds and investment funds and resign from numerous board positions as he tries to disentangle himself from potential conflicts of interest before his confirmation as the next Treasury secretary.

articles.title: Another Goldman Executive Is Said to Be Going to Trump Administration

articles.title: The Volvo S90 Is Very Swedish, and Very Appealing

Several years ago, more than a few analysts and journalists predicted that Volvo would go the way of Plymouth, Oldsmobile, Mercury and Scion, all shuttered brands. Volvo, once an independent Swedish company, was a part of Ford for a spell, and during that period its designs and engineering grew old. Too little change can be lethal.

articles.content: Well, that sure escalated quickly.

articles.content: BlackRock, the world’s largest publicly traded money manager, reported a slight decrease in profit for its full fiscal year on Friday, reflecting the jittery mood of investors and the broader volatility of stock and bond markets in 2016.

articles.title: Head of Sony Entertainment, Michael Lynton, to Step Down

articles.title: Tax Refund Loans Are Revamped and Resurrected

articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The board of Uber is confident in its chief executive, Travis Kalanick, board member Arianna Huffington said on Tuesday, providing a show of support as the embattled ride-hailing company seeks to repair its reputation.

articles.title: Congress Moves to Strike Internet Privacy Rules From Obama Era
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Republican senators moved Thursday to dismantle landmark internet privacy protections for consumers in the first decisive strike against telecommunications and technology regulations created during the Obama administration, and a harbinger of further deregulation.

articles.title: AT&T and Johnson & Johnson Pull Ads From YouTube
articles.content: AT&T and Johnson & Johnson, among the biggest advertisers in the United States, were among several companies to say Wednesday that they would stop their ads from running on YouTube and other Google properties amid concern that Google is not doing enough to prevent brands from appearing next to offensive material, like hate speech.

articles.title: North Korea Said to Be Target of Inquiry Over $81 Million Cyberheist
articles.content: Federal prosecutors are investigating North Korea’s possible role in the theft of $81 million from the central bank of Bangladesh in what security officials fear could be a new front in cyberwarfare.

articles.title: ‘Budget for Everything’: Basing Life on What You Can Afford
articles.content: In a recent article, “Basing Life on What You Can Afford,” a dozen freelance writers from around the country gathered stories from people in their communities about the financial trade-offs they make nearly every day.

articles.title: Eton Park to Shut Down as $3 Trillion Hedge Fund Industry Faces Turmoil
articles.content: A well-known money manager is shutting down his firm after a year of disappointing results — the latest sign of turmoil in the $3 trillion hedge fund industry.

articles.title: Video Review: Mini Countryman Takes On the Big Boys
articles.content: Going by name alone, Jamba Juice is not the kind of place with steak on the menu. Men’s wear at Dress Barn? Nope. Nor will you find big sport utility vehicles and crossovers, so popular with Americans, in a Mini showroom. That’s not to say the brand isn’t trying.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: The Next Front in Cyberwarfare
articles.content: One of the biggest bank robberies of all time has shown what could be the next front in cyberwarfare.

articles.title: Tech Roundup: Why Regulation Benefits (Yes, Benefits) Electric Cars
articles.content: A common piece of wisdom in business circles is that regulation is bad and stifles innovation.

articles.title: Sorting Messages on Gmail
articles.content: Q. I missed switching over to the new version of Google that separates different categories of messages. Is it too late to get set up like that? The number of emails I get is overwhelming.

articles.title: Self-Driving Cars Could Be Boon for Aged, After Initial Hurdles
articles.content: Single, childless and 68, Steven Gold has begun to think about future mobility and independence. Although in good health, he can foresee a time when he won’t be a confident driver, if he can drive at all. While he hopes to continue to live in his suburban Detroit home, he wonders how he will be able to get to places like his doctor’s office and the supermarket if his driving becomes impaired.

articles.title: Tech Roundup: A Senate Vote Is Not the Final Word on Internet Privacy
articles.content: Those rules meant to protect the privacy of your internet activity that you may have heard about? Never mind.

articles.title: Billionaire Investor Raises Stake in Tronc, and Feud With Its Chairman
articles.content: When Patrick Soon-Shiong, a billionaire doctor in Los Angeles, invested $70.5 million last May in what was then Tribune Publishing, the deal was viewed as not just an alliance between him and Michael W. Ferro Jr., the company’s new chairman, but a commitment to journalism itself.

articles.title: Cornell Law to Start Program on Roosevelt Island
articles.content: Cornell Law School, one of the top-ranked law schools in the nation, plans to offer a new juris doctorate program at the soon-to-be opened Cornell Tech campus on Roosevelt Island in New York City.

articles.title: Gershon Kekst, Leader in Wall St. Public Relations, Dies at 82
articles.content: Gershon Kekst, a corporate adviser who counseled many of the biggest deal makers during the merger boom of the 1980s and helped form the modern financial public relations industry, died on March 17 in New York. He was 82.

articles.title: A New Twist in iHeartMedia’s Debt Struggles
articles.content: In a restructuring world dominated by oil and gas companies on the one hand and retail on the other, iHeartMedia stands out.

articles.title: California Upholds Auto Emissions Standards, Setting Up Face-Off With Trump
articles.content: California’s clean-air agency voted on Friday to push ahead with stricter emissions standards for cars and trucks, setting up a potential legal battle with the Trump administration over the state’s plan to reduce planet-warming gases.

articles.title: C.I.A. Developed Tools to Spy on Mac Computers, WikiLeaks Disclosure Shows
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The C.I.A. developed tools to spy on Mac computers by injecting software into the chips that control the computers’ fundamental operations, according to the latest cache of classified government documents published on Thursday by WikiLeaks.

articles.title: Fake Sleuths: Web Gets It Wrong on London Attacker
articles.content: Hours after the terrorist attack in London, online sleuths thought they had identified the assailant.

articles.title: U.S., in Reversal, Issues Permit for Keystone Oil Pipeline
articles.content: HOUSTON — During his presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump repeatedly hailed the Keystone XL pipeline as a vital jobs program and one that sharply contrasted his vision for the economy with that of Hillary Clinton.

articles.title: SeaWorld Stake, Long Held by Blackstone, Is Sold to Chinese Firm
articles.content: Over seven years, the Blackstone Group nearly tripled its investment in SeaWorld, the home of Shamu and other killer whales.

articles.title: Uber Suspends Tests of Self-Driving Vehicles After Arizona Crash
articles.content: Uber said on Saturday that it was suspending the testing of its self-driving vehicles, a day after one of the vehicles was involved in a collision in Tempe, Ariz.

articles.title: North Korea’s Rising Ambition Seen in Bid to Breach Global Banks
articles.content: When hackers associated with North Korea tried to break into Polish banks late last year they left a trail of information about their apparent intentions to steal money from more than 100 organizations around the world, according to security researchers.

articles.title: Alex Jones Apologizes for Promoting ‘Pizzagate’ Hoax
articles.content: Alex Jones, a prominent conspiracy theorist and the host of a popular right-wing radio show, has apologized for helping to spread and promote the hoax known as Pizzagate.

articles.title: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: YouTube’s Problematic Advertising
articles.content: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

articles.title: One Nation, Under Fox: 18 Hours With a Network That Shapes America
articles.content: “I know maybe the president is watching.”

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 27
articles.content: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

articles.title: More Than Obamacare Repeal, Small Businesses Want Congress to Rein In Costs
articles.content: LaRonda Hunter, a business owner in Fort Worth, Tex., views the Affordable Care Act as a literal job killer. Fearful of triggering the law’s employer mandate, which requires businesses with 50 or more workers to offer health insurance or pay penalties, Ms. Hunter has held off on expanding her small chain of hair salons.

articles.title: Consumer Confidence Readings Due; Britain Prepares to Exit the E.U.
articles.content: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

articles.title: Brands Try to Blacklist Breitbart, but Ads Slip Through Anyway
articles.content: Since the presidential election, hundreds of companies have decided to block their advertisements from running on Breitbart News, the alt-right website closely tied to President Trump’s administration. But several of those brands, from the Nordstrom department store chain to small start-ups, have appeared on the site anyway, another example of how little control companies often have over where their ads are seen online.

articles.title: Publishers Retreat From the Risks of Google-YouTube Advertising
articles.content: When The Guardian was made aware this month that some of its advertisements were appearing on YouTube videos from extremists, it quickly pulled its marketing across Google. That move, prompted by reporting in The Times of London, began a broader advertiser exodus that has now extended to the United States, amid concern that the technology giant is not doing enough to prevent brands from showing up next to offensive content.

articles.title: Push for Internet Privacy Rules Moves to Statehouses
articles.content: Now that Republicans are in charge, the federal government is poised to roll back regulations limiting access to consumers’ online data. States have other ideas.

articles.title: In Rare Move, Chinese Think Tank Criticizes Tepid Pace of Reform
articles.content: BEIJING — China’s ambitious plan to revamp its economy has bogged down. Flabby state conglomerates have thwarted attempts to whip them into commercial shape. Rules that treat millions of city-dwelling rural migrants like second-class citizens have barely budged.

articles.title: Tronc Feud Escalates as Billionaire Investor Demands Access to Records
articles.content: Patrick Soon-Shiong, a billionaire doctor in Los Angeles and a major shareholder in the newspaper publisher Tronc, has sent a letter to Tronc’s board accusing the company of “poor corporate governance” and asking for access to its books and records.

articles.title: Tax on Saudi Aramco Oil Profits Is Cut to Prepare for I.P.O.
articles.content: Saudi Arabia announced a sharp tax cut for its state oil company on Monday, part of an effort to make it more appealing to international investors in preparation for its promised initial public offering.

articles.title: What the Future of S.E.C. Enforcement Holds Under Jay Clayton
articles.content: A frequently told story about the Securities and Exchange Commission’s adoption of Rule 10b-5, the principal antifraud rule used in hundreds of cases every year, is that after the five commissioners reviewed the proposal, the only one to speak was Sumner Pike, who simply said, “Well, we are against fraud, aren’t we?”

articles.title: Bill Gross and Pimco Settle Suit Over His Ouster
articles.content: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — A bitter legal war between the bond investor William H. Gross and Pimco, the company he built into one of the biggest asset managers in the world, is over.

articles.title: The Top 20 Venture Capitalists Worldwide
articles.content: These 20 venture capitalists – the investors who unearth the tiny start-ups that turn into tomorrow’s behemoths – are on the winningest streaks.

articles.title: Escaping the Scareware Alert
articles.content: Q. I sometimes get obviously fake virus alerts invading my desktop browser, but the only option to make the box go away is to click the O.K. button — which I am afraid to do. Where do these things come from, and is there an easier way to get out of this besides shutting down the whole computer?

articles.title: New Chairman at Paramount Pictures Faces an Arduous Task
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Viacom has turned to one of Hollywood’s most seasoned and respected executives, James N. Gianopulos, to revive its faded Paramount Pictures operation.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Icahn’s Role Raises Ethics Flags
articles.content: Carl C. Icahn is known for his pugnacious and persistent approach to activist investing.

articles.title: Supreme Court Considers Why Patent Trolls Love Texas
articles.content: WASHINGTON — More than 40 percent of patent lawsuits are filed in a federal court in East Texas with a reputation for friendliness to plaintiffs. That curious fact was the backdrop for a Supreme Court argument on Monday over whether the court should halt what many big technology companies say is pernicious forum shopping in patent cases.

articles.title: Equal Pay for Men and Women? Iceland Wants Employers to Prove It
articles.content: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — On a chilly afternoon in October, Frida Ros Valdimarsdottir, a former home-care worker turned women’s rights advocate, left her office at exactly 2:38 p.m. and headed to Reykjavik’s main square, where throngs of women were forming a boisterous crowd. It was the time — roughly two and a half hours before the end of the workday — that many protesters reckoned they stopped being paid for equal work.

articles.title: A Dearth of I.P.O.s, but It’s Not the Fault of Red Tape
articles.content: The confirmation hearing last week for Jay Clayton, who has been nominated to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, focused on the continued sluggishness of the market for initial public offerings. Senators pushed the nominee to do something, anything, to revive it.

articles.title: Ford to Expand U.S. Production of Trucks and S.U.V.s
articles.content: DETROIT — President Trump’s goal of stimulating growth in the American auto industry is getting a big push from the seemingly insatiable appetite of consumers for more trucks and sport utility vehicles.

articles.title: Saudis’ Tax Cut on Aramco Sweetens Its I.P.O.
articles.content: Saudi Arabia has hit on a cheap way to spruce up the odds for its big oil producer’s initial public offering: Cut its taxes.

articles.title: Facebook Mirrors Snapchat (Again) With Stories Feature
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Snapchat pioneered a feature named Stories, which lets people share their photographs or videos to tell a tale about their day or trip or event. After 24 hours, the Stories disappear.

articles.title: ‘Carnage’ Indeed, but Trump’s Policies Would Make It Worse
articles.content: Donald J. Trump can be brilliant. On the campaign trail, his diagnosis of the raw anger and disillusionment among white working-class Americans bested the most sophisticated analyses from the professional political class.

articles.title: Citing Misdeeds, U.S. Gives Wells Fargo Failing Grade on Lending
articles.content: In the latest blow to Wells Fargo’s efforts to rebuild its reputation after months of turmoil, the bank on Tuesday received a failing score on community lending from its federal regulator.

articles.title: Tesco’s British Unit Is Set to Avoid Criminal Charges in Accounting Scandal
articles.content: LONDON — The British supermarket giant Tesco said on Tuesday that its domestic business had reached an agreement in principle to avoid criminal charges in an accounting scandal that rocked the company nearly three years ago.

articles.title: Tencent of China Takes 5 Percent Stake in Tesla
articles.content: Tencent Holdings, one of China’s internet giants, has acquired a 5 percent stake in Elon Musk’s electric-car maker Tesla, according to a filing with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday.

articles.title: Trump’s Take on Corporate Tax Rate Could Look Very Much Like Obama’s
articles.content: Just a few days after being sworn in as president, Donald J. Trump convened a meeting at the White House of some of the nation’s most prominent chief executives to discuss how to improve manufacturing. Mr. Trump was joined by Elon Musk of Tesla, Mark Fields of Ford, Andrew Liveris of Dow Chemical, Marillyn A. Hewson of Lockheed Martin and Michael Dell of Dell, among others.

articles.title: Sometimes, Spending Brings a Bigger Return Than Saving
articles.content: Life experiences give you an incalculable return on investment. Every. Single. Time. So why is it so hard for us to spend money on them?

articles.title: Morning Agenda: The Robots Are Coming ... for Your Stocks
articles.content: Laurence D. Fink, the founder and chief executive of BlackRock, has cast his lot with the machines.

articles.title: Justices Side With Free-Speech Challenge to Credit Card Fees
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that the First Amendment applies to a New York law concerning credit card fees.

articles.title: Samsung, After Combustible Galaxy Note 7, Unveils New Smartphone
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Dogged by combustible smartphones and recalls of other devices, Samsung Electronics is hoping to find a path to product redemption.

articles.title: Westinghouse Files for Bankruptcy, in Blow to Nuclear Power
articles.content: Westinghouse Electric Company, which helped drive the development of nuclear energy and the electric grid itself, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, casting a shadow over the global nuclear industry.

articles.title: Valeant Bet Was a ‘Huge Mistake,’ Hedge Fund Chief Ackman Says
articles.content: It is rare that William A. Ackman, the brash activist investor, apologizes for anything. As a successful hedge fund manager, Mr. Ackman has made billions of dollars for himself and his investors with bold and counterintuitive bets.

articles.title: Look for Market Buoyancy Ahead of ‘Brexit’ to Be Short-Lived
articles.content: Divorce can be messy, even when both sides start out wanting an amicable settlement. Brexit may well work the same way now that Prime Minister Theresa May has started the process for Britain’s exit from the European Union.

articles.title: Little Sign of a ‘Trump Bump’ in the Economic Forecast
articles.content: Consumers are more confident. Stocks are up 5 percent since the start of the year. And from the president on down, there’s talk of a Trump bump.

articles.title: How to Use Technology to Outsource Pet Care
articles.content: Smartphones have become the go-to tool for hailing a car and ordering delivery food. But summoning a dog walker? That could take some getting used to.

articles.title: Is It a Toy? Is It Art? Everyone Agrees It’s a Collectible
articles.content: It stands four feet high, looks like a squat monkey with a giant head and doubles as a chalkboard that can be drawn on and wiped clean. And it costs $5,000.

articles.title: As Auto Prices Rise, Used Cars Are Looking Shinier
articles.content: Dennis McNabb had just started thinking about buying a roomier car last year when he suddenly had no choice. A heavy storm rolled across Texas and dropped golf-ball-size hail that pummeled his 2013 Hyundai Genesis and punched holes in the sedan’s windows.

articles.title: New Firms Catching Up to Banks in Foreclosure Rankings
articles.content: The number of home foreclosures is down sharply from the depths of the financial crisis, even as many of the mortgage firms involved remain the same, including Fannie Mae, Wells Fargo, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase.

articles.title: Uber Executive Invokes Fifth Amendment, Seeking to Avoid Potential Charges

articles.title: Oculus Founder, at Center of Legal Battle Over VR, Departs Facebook

articles.title: Google’s Claim Against Former Executive Could Help Uber in Driverless-Car Lawsuit
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Several months before filing a lawsuit against Uber, Google demanded arbitration against the head of Uber’s self-driving car unit, claiming that he used confidential salary information while trying to poach former colleagues to a new venture that he eventually sold to Uber.

articles.title: Chase Had Ads on 400,000 Sites. Then on Just 5,000. Same Results.
articles.content: As of a few weeks ago, advertisements for JPMorgan Chase were appearing on about 400,000 websites a month. It is the sort of eye-popping number that has become the norm these days for big companies that use automated tools to reach consumers online.

articles.title: Net Neutrality Is Trump’s Next Target, Administration Says
articles.content: The Trump administration served notice on Thursday that its next move to deregulate broadband internet service companies would be to jettison the Obama administration’s net neutrality rules, which were intended to safeguard free expression online.

articles.title: Beginning ‘Brexit’ and Bracing for Impact
articles.content: LONDON — The world did not end. No recession unfolded. Nine months after Britain voted to leave the European Union, disregarding warnings of grim economic consequences, a nation famous for calmly carrying on has seemingly gone about its business.

articles.title: Senate Narrowly Passes Rollback of Obama-Era ‘Auto-I.R.A.’ Rule
articles.content: WASHINGTON — By a single vote, the Senate gave final approval on Thursday to a measure to block cities and counties from organizing retirement savings accounts for workers who have no access to employer-sponsored plans. The vote reverses a Labor Department rule that allows local governments to automatically enroll private-sector workers in retirement plans unless they opt out.

articles.title: Twitter Bot — or Not?
articles.content: Q. How do I know if a Twitter account following me is a bot or a person?

articles.title: Student Loan Forgiveness Program Approval Letters May Be Invalid, Education Dept. Says
articles.content: More than 550,000 people have signed up for a federal program that promises to repay their remaining student loans after they work 10 years in a public service job.

articles.title: Dandelion Crayon Gets an Early Retirement From Crayola
articles.content: After 27 years, the crayon color dandelion is taking a retirement, making way for an upstart in the blue family, officials with the crayon company Crayola said on Friday.

articles.title: Lone Star to Buy Controlling Stake in Portugal’s Novo Banco
articles.content: LONDON — The Bank of Portugal, that nation’s central bank, said on Friday that it would sell a controlling stake in a bank salvaged from the collapse of one of the country’s largest private lenders, to Lone Star Funds, an American private equity firm.

articles.title: Giving Like a Rockefeller, Even if You’re Not Super-Rich
articles.content: David Rockefeller, who died last week at 101, was a giant among American philanthropists. He continued the tradition of giving that ran from his grandfather, John D., the founder of Standard Oil; through his father, John Jr.; and his oldest brother, John III.

articles.title: Volkswagen to Pay 10 States Over Environmental Claims
articles.content: DETROIT — Volkswagen took another step Thursday to move past its emissions-cheating scandal by agreeing to pay $157 million to 10 states to settle environmental lawsuits.

articles.title: I.R.S. Extension Adds Time to File, but You Still Have to Pay
articles.content: The April 18 deadline for filing federal income tax returns is fast approaching. Taxpayers who think that they will not complete their returns on time may want to consider filing extensions.

articles.title: Trump Critics on Climate Policy Hope Executives Can Sway Him
articles.content: Jeffrey R. Immelt, General Electric’s chief executive, says climate change is real, a position at odds with the Trump administration.

articles.title: Why the Urge to Merge Could Return to Wall Street

articles.title: Our Best Guidance for Filing Your Tax Return
articles.content: Are you filing with an online tool? Seeing a professional? Have you thought about your H.S.A.? Are you just out of time and need to file an extension?

articles.title: Also Made in Mexico: Lifesaving Medical Devices
articles.content: TIJUANA, Mexico — The North American Free Trade Agreement has transformed this sprawling border town from gritty party spot to something entirely different: a world capital of medical devices.

articles.title: Bill O’Reilly Thrives at Fox News, Even as Harassment Settlements Add Up
articles.content: For nearly two decades, Bill O’Reilly has been Fox News’s top asset, building the No. 1 program in cable news for a network that has pulled in billions of dollars in revenues for its parent company, 21st Century Fox.

articles.title: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: When Twitter Confuses and Facebook Copies

articles.title: Foreigners Have Long Mined Indonesia, but Now There’s an Outcry
articles.content: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Crowned with spiky feathered headdresses and daubed with face paint, scores of protesters gathered outside the Jakarta offices of an American mining giant last week, chanting, waving signs and throwing uncertainty into global commodities markets.

articles.title: Pamela Edstrom, Who Helped Shape Microsoft’s Public Image, Dies at 71
articles.content: Pamela Edstrom, a communications strategist who shaped the public image of Microsoft and its founder Bill Gates during the company’s reign as the most powerful technology player in the world, died on Tuesday at her home in Vancouver, Wash. She was 71.

articles.title: Bannon Made Millions in Shaping Right-Wing Thought
articles.content: The personal wealth and holdings of President Trump’s chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon, were detailed for the first time on Friday in a filing that showed a large chunk of his income coming from right-leaning political news, film and consulting companies.

articles.title: Alex Tizon, Journalist Who Wrote of Alienation as Asian-American, Dies at 57
articles.content: Alex Tizon, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter whose well-received 2014 memoir documented his insecurities and alienation as a Filipino-American, was found dead on March 23 in his home in Eugene, Ore. He was 57.

articles.title: President’s Growing Trade Gap: A Gulf Between Talk and Action
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Increasingly, when it comes to foreign trade, the Trump administration is talking loudly and brandishing a small stick.

articles.title: Dyson Is the Apple of Appliances (and Just as Secretive)
articles.content: MALMESBURY, England — When Michael Aldred joined the British home electronics maker Dyson two decades ago, he had a simple goal: to quickly build a robotic vacuum cleaner.

articles.title: How Uber Uses Psychological Tricks to Push Its Drivers’ Buttons
articles.content: The start-up has undertaken an extraordinary experiment in behavioral science to subtly entice an independent work force to maximize company revenue.

articles.title: Engineering, the Dyson Way
articles.content: Dyson was built on the re-engineering of the vacuum cleaner, but it has come a long way since then, and its ambitions are far larger.

articles.title: The Ad Feels a Bit Like Oscar Bait, but It’s Trying to Sell You an iPhone
articles.content: Carrie Brownstein, the actress known for the series “Portlandia,” wrote and directed a short film last fall that pokes fun at the exaggerated comments people post under pictures of celebrities on social media, showing what would happen if reverential remarks like “Mom” or “marry me” played out in the real world.

articles.title: Facebook Pushes Outside Law Firms to Become More Diverse
articles.content: Like other Silicon Valley giants, Facebook has faced criticism over whether its work force and board are too white and too male. Last year, the social media behemoth started a new push on diversity in hiring and retention.

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 3
articles.content: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

articles.title: Trump Plans Have Deal Makers Dreaming Big ($100-Billion-Cash-Takeover Big)
articles.content: NEW ORLEANS — It wasn’t just cocktails on Bourbon Street or lucky breaks at the blackjack tables that contributed to the buoyant mood of the deal makers who gathered here last week. President Trump — and his support for lower taxes and lighter regulations — also had something to do with it.

articles.title: Richard Bolles Dies at 90; Wrote ‘What Color Is Your Parachute?’
articles.content: Richard N. Bolles, a former Harvard physics major, Episcopal minister and career counselor whose own twisting vocational path led to his writing “What Color Is Your Parachute?” — the most popular job-hunter’s manual of the 1970s and beyond — died on Friday in San Ramon, Calif. He was 90.

articles.title: March Figures for New Car Sales and Hiring Are on the Way
articles.content: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

articles.title: Tesla Reports Jump in Vehicle Production but Aims for Much More
articles.content: Tesla, the electric-car maker, on Sunday reported strong year-on-year jumps in vehicle deliveries and production in the first quarter, although it still must navigate a key challenge later this year to hit the ambitious targets that its chief executive, Elon Musk, has set for 2018.

articles.title: Volkswagen Share Sale Keeps the Automaker a Family Affair
articles.content: Ferdinand Piëch, a former chief executive of Volkswagen who was a dominant presence at the carmaker for more than two decades, has agreed to sell most of his 15 percent stake in the family holding company to his relatives rather than to an outside investor. The stake was valued at more than $1 billion.

articles.title: Reckitt Benckiser Review Could Put French’s Mustard Up for Sale
articles.content: LONDON — French’s mustard and Frank’s Red Hot sauce may become the latest mainstays of American kitchens to go up for sale.

articles.title: When Conspiracy and Forfeiture Law Intersect
articles.content: Justice Robert H. Jackson once wrote that “the modern crime of conspiracy is so vague that it almost defies definition.”

articles.title: New York Times Elevates Sam Dolnick to Masthead
articles.content: The New York Times continues to add to the ranks of its top newsroom editors.

articles.title: Credit Suisse Tax Inquiry Puts Spotlight on Private Bank Model
articles.content: Credit Suisse knows the importance of keeping its nose clean.

articles.title: Replacing a Photo in Your Facebook Post
articles.content: Q. After I crop and touch up a picture from my phone camera, I sometimes post the wrong one to my Facebook account because it’s hard to tell which version is which from the little preview images. Normally, I just delete the post with the wrong photo and upload the right one, but sometimes I don’t notice right away and people have already commented. Is there a way to replace the old picture with the new one without losing the comments?

articles.title: The Digital Nomad Life: Combining Work and Travel
articles.content: On a recent afternoon in Medellín, Colombia, a group of 22 out-of-towners gathered to brainstorm and then met up with locals.

articles.title: Tech Roundup: Google’s Ad Issues Expose a Vulnerability
articles.content: There was a time when IBM was a monopolistic giant that looked indestructible. And there was a time when Microsoft looked like the tech company that could never be beaten.

articles.title: Butter or Margarine? In Dunkin’ Donuts Lawsuit, Man Accepts No Substitutes
articles.content: If you order chicken, you expect chicken.

articles.title: Jason Blum, Producer Behind ‘Get Out,’ Is Starting a TV Company
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Jason Blum, the producing whiz behind blockbuster horror films like “Get Out” and “Split,” has secured funding from ITV Studios in Britain to start a stand-alone television company. The first of several projects, a mini-series called “Secure and Hold: The Last Days of Roger Ailes,” is already in the works at Showtime.

articles.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
articles.content: $3.5 MILLION

articles.title: Downtown Brooklyn’s Dearth of Office Space Beckons Tishman Speyer
articles.content: Tishman Speyer, one of the city’s largest and oldest commercial landlords, is making its first foray into Brooklyn. The developer, which owns such trophy office properties as Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building, is constructing a 620,000-square-foot office tower on top of the Macy’s department store in Downtown Brooklyn.

articles.title: Tesla Passes Ford in Market Value as Investors Bet on the Future
articles.content: DETROIT — The record pace of auto sales in the United States is slowing down, leaving investors increasingly bearish on auto stocks.

articles.title: To Curb Global Warming, Science Fiction May Become Fact
articles.content: Remember “Snowpiercer”?

articles.title: Changes to Tech Worker Visas Are Cosmetic. For Now.
articles.content: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services announced on Friday that it was reversing its previous guidance that entry-level computer programming jobs automatically qualify as a “specialty occupation” — a basic requirement for receiving an H-1B work visa. And on Monday, the Justice Department warned that it would look closely at any employer who discriminates against American workers by showing a preference for hiring H-1B workers.

articles.title: Trump Completes Repeal of Online Privacy Protections From Obama Era
articles.content: President Trump on Monday signed a congressional resolution to complete the overturning of internet privacy protections created by the Federal Communications Commission during the Obama administration.

articles.title: Tech Roundup: Changes to the H-1B Visa Program Begin
articles.content: While campaigning for president last year, Donald J. Trump promised changes to the H-1B visa program that brings skilled foreign workers to the United States. A critique of the program is that it can be used to replace American workers with cheaper foreign labor. Critics say that Indian outsourcing firms, in particular, use it as a shortcut to make low bids on contracts.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Understaffed Treasury Isn’t Ready for Tax Overhaul

articles.title: After Ailes, the Pirate Flag Still Flies at Fox News
articles.content: Throughout Fox News Channel’s summer of discontent last year, executives at its parent company, 21st Century Fox, assured reporters that the young, up-and-coming corporate leadership — Rupert Murdoch’s sons, James and Lachlan — understood the severity of the sexual harassment allegations pending against the network’s founding chairman, Roger E. Ailes.

articles.title: A Toy for Toddlers Doubles as Code Bootcamp

articles.title: At F.C.C., Obama-Era Rules on Chopping Block

articles.title: For Internet Privacy, VPNs Are an Imperfect Shield

articles.title: Backing Up Vacation Photos on the Go
articles.content: Q. I plan to take a lot of pictures on my next trip and load them to my laptop for storage and editing. I don’t want to do online backup on the road for fear of unfamiliar wireless networks in foreign countries, and I don’t want to haul a bulky USB drive around. What are my other options for backing up a lot of high-resolution photos?

articles.title: Bank Reform Architect Puzzled by Effort to Undo It
articles.content: Barney Frank is puzzled.

articles.title: Study Finds Car Insurers Raise Rates in Minority Neighborhoods
articles.content: A new analysis of car insurance in four states found that drivers living in some minority neighborhoods were charged higher rates than similar drivers in mostly white areas, even when the average risk of a claim was similar.

articles.title: Woman Who Got Settlement From O’Reilly Criticizes Trump for Defending Him
articles.content: One of the women who received a settlement from Bill O’Reilly after making sexual harassment allegations against the top-rated Fox News host sharply criticized President Trump on Wednesday for defending Mr. O’Reilly.

articles.title: Wall Street and Washington: A New Love Affair
articles.content: Repealing Obamacare. Reforming the tax system. Spending big on infrastructure.

articles.title: Jeff Bezos Says He Is Selling $1 Billion a Year in Amazon Stock to Finance Race to Space
articles.content: COLORADO SPRINGS — Standing against the backdrop of his New Shepard rocket booster and a full-scale mock capsule for carrying humans into space, Jeff Bezos revealed on Wednesday that he was selling about $1 billion in Amazon stock a year to finance his Blue Origin rocket company.

articles.title: Soon, Your Car May Be Able to Read Your Expressions
articles.content: When you shop for cat food online, Amazon knows who you are. When you look for the best airfares for summer vacation, Google knows who you are. Soon, when you get behind the wheel, your car may recognize you, too.

articles.title: Ex-Director of F.B.I. Is Picked to Oversee Takata Restitution
articles.content: Robert S. Mueller III, the former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is set to oversee nearly $1 billion that the airbag maker Takata has agreed to pay to victims and automakers affected by its defective airbags.

articles.title: Unilever to Sell Its Spreads Business and Restructure
articles.content: LONDON — Under pressure after spurning a blockbuster $143 billion takeover offer, Unilever said on Thursday that it would explore the sale of its spreads business, restructure two major divisions, review its dual legal structure and buy back $5.3 billion in stock as it seeks to cut costs and appease investors.

articles.title: Video Review: Hardtop MX-5 Miata RF Gains Elegance but Loses Openness
articles.content: Do you like the idea of slicing through traffic in a Mazda MX-5 Miata but have stopped short of owning it for fear vandals will slice through the soft top? Two letters should alleviate that anxiety: RF. This version of Mazda’s diminutive smile machine has a solid folding roof impervious to knives. It’s quieter while driving with the top up, too.

articles.title: Renaud Laplanche, Ousted at Lending Club, Returns as Rival to His Old Firm

articles.title: Different Portraits of a Gambler as a Trader Emerge at Trial

articles.title: Twitter Sues the Government to Block the Unmasking of an Account Critical of Trump
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter sued the federal government on Thursday to block the unmasking of an anonymous account that has posted messages critical of the Trump administration and has claimed to have ties to a government agency.

articles.title: F.D.A. Will Allow 23andMe to Sell Genetic Tests for Disease Risk to Consumers

articles.title: 7-Eleven’s Parent Will Buy Sunoco’s Convenience Stores

articles.title: The Witty and Weird of Passover Products (Matzo Print Attire, No Less)

There’s the food (a tradition itself) that is always served in a particular snowflake-dappled bowl at Christmas or on the special bunny-shaped platter at Easter. There are the salt-and-pepper shakers in the shape of Pilgrims that are trotted out at Thanksgiving. And, of course, there are the occasional new acquisitions.

articles.title: Even Amid Trade Tensions, Ford Pushes Pickup Trucks in China

articles.title: Panicked Borrowers, and the Education Department’s Unsettling Silence

articles.title: Uber Denies It Is Using Stolen Waymo Technology

articles.title: Spotify May Go Public Without Raising Capital

articles.title: An Alternate Plan in Case of a 911 Failure

articles.title: Tomi Lahren Sues Glenn Beck, Saying She Was Fired for Her Stance on Abortion
articles.content: Tomi Lahren, a fiery, fast-talking rising star in conservative media, on Friday sued her employer and its founder, the right-wing media personality Glenn Beck, claiming they fired her to retaliate after she revealed her support for abortion rights.

articles.title: No ‘Death Spiral’: Insurers May Soon Profit From Obamacare Plans, Analysis Finds

articles.title: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Why We’ll Miss Walt Mossberg

articles.title: Bill O’Reilly’s Family Values Book Tops Charts, as He Faces Abuse Claims

articles.title: To Woo Young Moviegoers, AMC Thinks More Like McDonald’s

articles.content: Rupert Murdoch has long sought to add Sky, the British satellite and news giant, to his stable of global media outlets that includes movie studios, newspapers and cable networks like Fox News.

articles.title: Can Bill O’Reilly Keep His Scold’s Perch?

Stumpf, and its former head of community banking, Carrie L. Tolstedt.

articles.title: Fox Asks Law Firm to Investigate Bill O’Reilly Harassment Claim

articles.title: WikiLeaks Documentary Evolves With Its Subject, Year After Premiere

articles.title: U.S. Accuses Russian Email Spammer of Vast Network of Fraud

They were rebuffed, a former American law enforcement official who was there said. The spammer, who used the pseudonym Peter Severa, was protected, probably by the Russian government, and could not be touched.

articles.content: How could this have happened? You might have wondered after the scandal over fraudulent accounts at Wells Fargo.

articles.title: A Hangout for Old Desktop Notifications

articles.title: That Fingerprint Sensor on Your Phone Is Not as Safe as You Think

With services like Apple Pay or Android Pay, a fingerprint can buy a bag of groceries, a new laptop or even a $1 million vintage Aston Martin. And pressing a finger inside a banking app allows a user to pay bills or transfer thousands of dollars.

But Angelenos have signaled that they are ready for a change, most recently by voting down a measure that would have slowed new construction for two years.

articles.title: Book Pins Corporate Greed on a Lust Bred at Harvard

articles.title: Trump Isn’t Wrong on China Currency Manipulation, Just Late

articles.title: A Chat With a Live Streamer Is Yours, for a Price

articles.title: Medical Debt: You May Not Owe It
articles.content: Nearly two-thirds of people who complained to federal regulators about medical debt collectors said they did not owe the money, a new report found.

articles.title: Melania Trump and Daily Mail Settle Her Libel Suits

articles.title: Venezuela Staves Off Default, but Low Oil Prices Pose a Threat

articles.title: Bill O’Reilly’s World: Books, Philanthropy and Speaking Engagements
articles.content: Bill O’Reilly is both an ambassador and a moneymaker for Fox News, his television home since 1996. His show, “The O’Reilly Factor,” which airs at 8 on weeknights, is routinely the highest-ranked show on cable news. And his blend of I-know-best commentary and pointed interviews established a genre of opinion programming that has come to dominate much of television news.

articles.title: Send Some Sass With That Text Message

articles.title: Ford Foundation Is an Unlikely Convert to ‘Impact’ Investing

He served a stint managing the endowment at Harvard, his alma mater, and he’s also a life trustee and member of the investment committee at Amherst College. He’s on multiple boards of nonprofit institutions, including the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation and St. Andrew’s Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

articles.title: The Murdochs Assess the O’Reilly Damage
articles.content: Bill O’Reilly left Fox News this week for a long-planned vacation to Italy and the Vatican, with his fate in the hands of a Murdoch family calculating the risks and rewards of keeping him on or forcing him out of the network.

articles.title: United Airlines Offers Refunds as Outrage at a Violent Removal Continues
articles.content: United Airlines struggled on Wednesday to respond to a third day of public outrage over widely shared videos of a passenger being dragged off an airplane, offering a refund to every passenger on the flight and promising to no longer have the police remove passengers from planes that are too full.

articles.title: Tech Roundup: Paying Up to $500 to Chat With a Live Streamer

articles.title: How Top Philanthropists Wield Power Through Their Donations
articles.content: Big philanthropic donations garner big attention. And any criticism of them often comes long after the ribbon-cutting, and even then it can seem churlish. These megadonors are giving money to benefit the public good that they could be spending on jets, estates and club memberships — or in most cases, more of the above.

articles.title: Amex, Challenged by Chase, Is Losing the Snob War

articles.title: In Farewell, Daniel Tarullo Offers Fixes on Bank Regulation

articles.title: United and Pepsi Affairs Force Brands to Respect Social Media

articles.title: Robert Taylor, Innovator Who Shaped Modern Computing, Dies at 85

articles.title: Germany Strikes Offshore Wind Deals, Subsidy Not Included

articles.title: In Reversal, Trump Names Pick to Reshape Export-Import Bank, Not End It

articles.title: Al Golin, PR Man Whose Vision Helped Make McDonald’s a Success, Dies at 87

articles.title: O’Reilly’s Behavior Said to Have Helped Drive Megyn Kelly Out at Fox

articles.title: Mike and Nicole’s Week in Tech: United’s Troubles and Burger King’s ‘Hack’
articles.content: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Farhad is out this week, so Nicole Perlroth, a Times cybersecurity reporter, is filling in.

articles.title: David Donaldson, Economist Who Studies Trade Benefits, Wins Clark Medal

articles.title: Hacking Group Claims N.S.A. Infiltrated Mideast Banking System

On Friday, just when its leaks had appeared to slow, the group released what appears to be its most damaging leak so far: a trove of highly classified hacking tools used to break into various Microsoft systems, along with what it said was evidence that the N.S.A. had infiltrated the backbone of the Middle East’s banking infrastructure.

articles.title: Slack, an Upstart in Messaging, Now Faces Giant Tech Rivals

articles.title: BP Struggles to Control Damaged Well in Alaskan Arctic

articles.title: Inside the Hotel Industry’s Plan to Combat Airbnb

articles.title: Marketing Natural Body Care Products, With a Side of Activism

articles.title: The Hotel Industry’s Plans to Combat Airbnb

articles.title: United Airlines Staff Will No Longer Take Seats of Boarded Passengers

articles.title: Even Before Ill-Advised Letter, Arconic’s C.E.O. Had to Go

Mr. Kleinfeld, the chairman and chief executive of Arconic, the Alcoa spinoff that makes specialty parts for cars and airplanes, stepped down on Monday for inappropriately writing a letter to an activist shareholder. That saves Arconic’s directors from having to fire him. But they will still have to answer for why they didn’t do that long ago.

articles.title: Overbooked: Readers’ Airline Stories
articles.content: Airlines have long found ways to entice passengers off their planes. Often, this is a result of flights’ being overbooked, as airlines try to fill as many seats as possible. When they overbook, airlines begin a process of bargaining with passengers at the gate, offering travel vouchers that usually range from $400 to $600, up to a maximum of $1,350, according to Transportation Department guidelines.

articles.title: Vijay Mallya, Once India’s ‘King of Good Times,’ Is Arrested in London
articles.content: LONDON — Vijay Mallya has spent a lifetime building a reputation as India’s professed King of Good Times, a flamboyant tycoon with investments in alcohol, an airline and an auto racing team. But his freewheeling, free-spending ways ended last year when he fled India under an avalanche of unpaid bills and accusations of fraud.

articles.title: New York Times Names Former Businessweek Editor to Head Business Section
articles.content: The New York Times continued to shake up its newsroom leadership on Tuesday by naming Ellen Pollock, formerly the editor in chief of Bloomberg Businessweek, the next top editor of its business section. articles.content: Several things have been credited with driving Stephen Colbert’s recent ratings surge: liberals craving a safe space, a backlash to his rival Jimmy Fallon’s  hair tousle of Donald J. Trump, and Mr. Colbert simply being more comfortable as the host of his late-night show on CBS.

articles.title: Erasing Your Android Tracks

articles.content: Once again, artificial intelligence triumphed over man.

articles.title: OPEC, Fighting Market Forces, Extends Production Cuts
articles.content: VIENNA — A sense of déjà vu pervaded the latest meeting of oil exporting countries. While production cuts have again bolstered oil prices, the optimism may fade, as shale producers in the United States jump back into the market and the rise of renewables dims prospects for demand.

articles.title: Video Review: Cadillac CT6 Adds ‘Sporty’ to the Luxury Lexicon

articles.title: Eyeglass Vendor, Imprisoned for Terrorizing Consumers, Is Accused of Fraud
articles.content: Vitaly Borker served a three-and-a-half-year stint in prison for threatening to stalk, maim and murder customers of his online eyeglass store, DecorMyEyes. But the court-ordered timeout, it seems, did little to convince him to take a new approach to sales.

articles.title: Don’t Be Fooled by Strong Earnings From Sears and Best Buy
articles.content: Several major retailers seem to be pulling back from the brink. Sears, Abercrombie & Fitch and Best Buy each reported encouraging numbers on Thursday. But Tiffany’s quarterly slump, reported a day ago, shows that hopes of a turnaround offer a false bill of goods.

articles.title: Rough Treatment of Journalists in the Trump Era
articles.content: For those concerned about press freedom, the first months of the Trump administration have been troubling. Journalists have been yelled at, pepper-sprayed, pinned by security and even arrested on the job. Now, one reporter has accused a Republican candidate of assault.

articles.title: Google’s A.I. Program Rattles Chinese Go Master as It Wins Match

articles.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s Great American Road Trip

articles.title: A Russian Businessman’s Road From Siberia to Success
