articles.title: Immigrants Keep an Iowa Meatpacking Town Alive and Growing
articles.content: Waves of Asian, African and Latino newcomers have filled jobs at pork, egg and turkey plants where wages have fallen and work has grown more grueling.

articles.title: Trump Course Solicits New Members
articles.content: The Trump National Golf Club in Virginia sent this letter soliciting membership and promoting its facilities.

articles.title: China Moves to Stabilize Currency, Despite Promise to Loosen Control
articles.content: HONG KONG — China has made a big show of gradually loosening its grip on the value of its currency, an effort meant to mollify critics like President Trump and experts who have long urged Beijing to let markets fix financial problems in the world’s second-largest economy.

articles.title: Big Payoff After Blackstone Courted a Saudi Prince
articles.content: A little over a year ago, the private equity titan Stephen A. Schwarzman sat down with Mohammed bin Salman, the deputy crown prince of Saudi Arabia and chairman of the kingdom’s largest sovereign wealth fund, in hopes of expanding their relationship.

articles.title: Review: How Laws of Physics Govern Growth in Business and in Cities
articles.content: The new book of Geoffrey West, a theoretical physicist, comes with a mouthful of a subtitle that suggests he has unlocked the secrets of human existence — “Scale: The Universal Laws of Growth, Innovation, Sustainability and the Pace of Life in Organisms, Cities, Economies, and Companies” (Penguin).

articles.title: To Invest in Your Child’s Theater Dreams, First Invest in the Theater
articles.content: Dean Roth, the owner and president of a New Jersey company that makes parts for the tool-and-die industry, admits he has utterly failed to talk his teenage daughter out of pursuing a career in musical theater.

articles.title: Trump Administration Considers Moving Student Loans from Education Department to Treasury
articles.content: The Trump administration is considering moving responsibility for overseeing more than $1 trillion in student debt from the Education Department to the Treasury Department, a switch that would radically change the system that helps 43 million students finance higher education.

articles.title: Jerry Perenchio, Entertainment Mogul Who Advised ‘Think Big,’ Dies at 86
articles.content: Jerry Perenchio, an entertainment mogul who promoted the Muhammad Ali-Joe Frazier heavyweight championship fight in 1971, produced television shows with Norman Lear and turned Univision into the dominant Hispanic TV network in the United States, died on Tuesday at his home in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 86.

articles.title: A Journalist Was Body Slammed, but Some Conservatives Want the News Media to Apologize
articles.content: In this time of intense partisanship, shiv-in-the-kidney politics and squabbles over the meaning of truth, can Americans come together and agree that a politician slamming a journalist to the ground for asking a question is wrong?

articles.title: Farhad’s and Sheera’s Week in Tech: The Dark, Terrifying World of Hackers
articles.content: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike was away this week, so Sheera Frenkel, a cybersecurity reporter for The Times, filled in.

articles.title: Ronald D. Croatti, Uniform Company Chief and Undercover Boss, Dies at 74
articles.content: Ronald D. Croatti, the chief executive of UniFirst, who spent his entire professional life supplying uniforms and apparel to some of the biggest manufacturing companies, died on Tuesday in Boston. He was 74.

articles.title: Mother of Uber Chief Executive Killed in Boating Accident
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The mother of Travis Kalanick, the chief executive of Uber, was killed and his father seriously injured in a boating accident on Friday near Fresno, Calif., the company said on Saturday.

articles.title: Have a Day Off? Tackle Your Financial To-Do List
articles.content: A long holiday weekend, with its promise of a few extra hours of free time, can be a good time to turn to tackling undone financial tasks.

articles.title: Route to Air Travel Discomfort Starts on Wall Street
articles.content: When an unlucky passenger was violently dragged off a full United Airlines flight in Chicago in April, setting off a public-relations nightmare for the company, the blame naturally fell on the cabin crew, the police and eventually airline executives.

articles.title: Hackers Hide Cyberattacks in Social Media Posts
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — It took only one attempt for Russian hackers to make their way into the computer of a Pentagon official. But the attack didn’t come through an email or a file buried within a seemingly innocuous document.

articles.title: The Coat of Arms Said ‘Integrity.’ Now It Says ‘Trump.’

articles.title: The Future of European Transit: Driverless and Utilitarian
articles.content: On the outskirts of Berlin, Michael Barillère-Scholz is testing a driverless vehicle that is neither sleek nor futuristic. The machine is boxy and painted white. Its top speed barely reaches 20 miles per hour.

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of May 29
articles.content: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

articles.title: Brands Expand Into New Niches With Care, but Not Without Risk
articles.content: The luxury sports carmaker Aston Martin recently unveiled plans to build Aston Martin Residences, a luxury condominium complex in Miami. Sales will start in July, with the condos scheduled to open in 2021. The car company didn’t jump into the real estate business willy-nilly, though. It is part of a gradual brand extension that began with high-end jewelry in 2012, speedboats in 2015, luxury men’s wear in 2016 and its “Art of Living” experiences, which include exotic road trips and Champagne tastings, in 2016.

articles.title: 2 Expected to Be Named to S.E.C. Enforcement Role

articles.title: When You See Something (Fake), Say Something

articles.title: Behind the Scenes at Orchard Platform, a Struggle to Innovate

articles.title: Payment Processor First Data to Buy CardConnect for $750 Million
articles.content: First Data agreed on Monday to buy CardConnect, a fellow payment processor, for about $750 million in cash including the repayment of debt, in its biggest takeover since going public in 2015.

articles.title: Immigrants Keep an Iowa Meatpacking Town Alive and Growing
articles.content: STORM LAKE, Iowa — When Dan Smith first went to work at the pork processing plant in Storm Lake in 1980, pretty much the only way to nab that kind of union job was to have a father, an uncle or a brother already there. The pay, he recalled, was $16 an hour, with benefits — enough to own a home, a couple of cars, a camper and a boat, while your wife stayed home with the children.

articles.title: When ‘Political Intelligence’ Meets Insider Trading
articles.content: A case involving insider trading charges based on government information dispensed by a “political intelligence” operative raises interesting questions about how some of the tricky rules for proving the offense will be applied when information is leaked from a federal agency rather than a corporation.

articles.title: After Technical Chaos, British Airways Looks to Restore Schedule

articles.title: Cornell’s Climate-Conscious Urban Campus Arises
articles.content: When Cornell University competed in 2011 to develop an applied science and engineering campus in New York City, part of its pitch was that it would construct an academic building that would at least approach making as much energy as it used in a year, a concept known as net zero. It won. Then came the hard work of making that vision happen at the campus, known as Cornell Tech.

articles.title: India’s Bad Debt Is Looking Better to Investors
articles.content: MUMBAI, India — In India, the vultures are circling.

articles.content: SYDNEY, Australia — Wall Street has started a bidding war for Fairfax Media, an Australian company best known for the dowdy business of publishing newspapers. To understand why, look no further than Deanna McMath.

articles.title: Scott Pelley Said to Be Leaving Post as ‘CBS Evening News’ Anchor
articles.content: Scott Pelley is leaving his anchor role with “CBS Evening News,” a position he has filled since 2011, two people familiar with the move said Tuesday.

articles.title: How Twitter Is Being Gamed to Feed Misinformation

The criticism was well placed: Facebook is the world’s most popular social network, and millions of people look to it daily for news.

articles.title: Megyn Kelly, on NBC With New Shows, Moves Past Trump Turmoil

articles.title: Exxon Vote on Climate Change Puts Other Companies on Notice

Over 60 percent of them backed a move that forces the $340 billion company to ramp up global-warming disclosure, up from under 40 percent in a similar attempt last year. Exxon already embraces the debate more than most. But shareholders want the company to be more forthcoming. Holdouts among their industry peers will have to follow or risk investor ire.

New-customer acquisition costs are surging, customers are ordering fewer meals, and competitors abound. Like Groupon before it, Blue Apron is a case where the product is fine but the stock is best avoided.

articles.content: Jack Trout, a marketing strategist who viewed business as a Clausewitzian battlefield in which companies outflank their rivals in part by embedding their messages in consumers’ minds through a concept known as positioning, died on Sunday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 82.

articles.title: Pinterest Raises Valuation to $12.3 Billion With New Funding
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Pinterest, the digital scrapbook company, has raised $150 million in a funding that raises its valuation to $12.3 billion.

articles.title: New York Times Co. Promotes Executive to Chief Operating Officer
articles.content: The New York Times announced on Wednesday that it had promoted Meredith Kopit Levien, who had been its chief revenue officer since 2015, to executive vice president and chief operating officer, as part of a restructuring of The Times’s digital departments.

articles.title: Five Big Tech Stocks Build Market Euphoria, and Jitters
articles.content: Facebook. Amazon. Apple. Netflix. Google.

articles.title: After Reality Winner’s Arrest, Media Asks: Did ‘Intercept’ Expose a Source?
articles.content: Journalism in the Trump era has featured a staggering number of leaks from sources across the federal government, providing bombshell revelations about everything from clandestine meetings with Russian officials to petty infighting at the White House.

articles.title: Debt Ceiling Is Again a Battleground, This Time with Republicans in Charge
articles.content: WASHINGTON — This summer was supposed to be a heady time for Republicans, who would be repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act, cutting taxes and simplifying the tax code, and reining in the reach of government.

articles.title: Rotterdam Climate Headline Here
articles.content: Rotterdam climate summary goes here

articles.title: The Benefits of Talking to Yourself
articles.content: A stranger approached me at a grocery store. “Do you need help finding something?” he asked. At first, I wasn’t sure what he meant. Then the realization kicked in: I was talking out loud, to myself, in public. It was a habit I’d grown so comfortable with that I didn’t even realize I was doing it.

articles.title: ‘Must-See TV’: Free Drinks and Canceled Meetings for Comey’s Testimony
articles.content: The schedule has been cleared and the popcorn readied at Evergreen Partners, a strategic communications firm in central New Jersey, where the rule for employees on Thursday morning is simple: No client talk while James B. Comey is speaking.

articles.title: Movers: Nordstrom Considers Leveraged Buyout
articles.content: Shares of Nordstrom, the department store chain, jumped more than 10 percent on Thursday as the Nordstrom family — which still owns a substantial minority of the stock — said it would explore going private.

articles.title: Bill to Erase Some Dodd-Frank Banking Rules Passes in House
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The House approved legislation on Thursday to erase a number of core financial regulations put in place by the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act, as Republicans moved a step closer to delivering on their promises to eliminate rules that they claim have strangled small businesses and stagnated the economy.

articles.title: Video Review: With New Ioniq, Hyundai Goes After Prius
articles.content: It is the most efficient gasoline-powered car you can buy in America. There’s generous room for four, five if need be. It’s quiet, comfortable and comes with a lifetime battery warranty. And it is not the Toyota Prius.

articles.title: Verizon to Lay Off 2,100 Employees After Finalizing Yahoo Deal
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Verizon plans to lay off 2,100 people once it completes its acquisition of Yahoo’s internet business on Tuesday.

articles.title: Matt Zames to Leave JPMorgan Chase, Seeking to Run His Own Business
articles.content: Matt Zames, the tough-minded chief operating officer of the banking colossus JPMorgan Chase, is unexpectedly resigning.

articles.title: Automakers Race to Get Ahead of Silicon Valley on Car-Sharing
articles.content: SEATTLE — On a recent overcast afternoon in this city’s Belltown neighborhood, a driver pulled up in a gleaming new BMW X1 sport utility vehicle just a few minutes after a few swipes of a smartphone app had summoned it.

articles.title: U.K. Election Delivers New Variable for Uncertain Global Economy
articles.content: LONDON — In a global economy amply stocked with anxiety-provoking variables, Britain just added another.

articles.title: Movers: Tech Stocks Fall Sharply
articles.content: Technology stocks stumbled on Friday, dragging down the Nasdaq composite index.

articles.title: Checking a Digital Photo’s Dimensions
articles.content: Q. Where do I find the dimensions of a digital photo on my computer? Amazon’s photofinishing service says the pictures need a resolution of “450 by 630” for a five-by-seven-inch print.

articles.title: Why I Am Giving My Children Their Inheritance Now
articles.content: I have worked for a man who owns his-and-her 747s. Another former employer has a 10,000-acre hobby farm he visits about 10 times a year. And, in a total coincidence, I have been hired by two people who each happen to own one of the 25 largest yachts in the world, boats that come with 12 times the living space of my house and are equipped not only with fully stocked wine cellars but also with helicopters and submarines.

articles.title: Drivers Head Into Summer With a Gift at the Gas Pump
articles.content: HOUSTON — Looking for an excuse to pack up the car for a road trip this weekend?

articles.title: Now, Your Financial Advisers Will Have to Put You First (Sometimes)
articles.content: When a doctor prescribes a drug, most people trust that it is the best course of treatment. The next time you seek financial advice, those professionals will be required to act in a way that approximates the patient-doctor relationship. But many investors will still remain vulnerable.

articles.title: The Monk Who Left the Monastery to Fix Broken Retirement Plans
articles.content: SANTA FE, N.M. — There are many things that Doug Lynam has to think about now that he no longer wears a robe and lives in a monastery. Socks, for one. Do they match? Should he care? “How does this color thing work?” he wondered aloud in his office this week while sporting a muted gray pair that did not in fact clash.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Pound Suffers on Hung Parliament in U.K.
articles.content: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain has lost her gamble, and the pound is paying for it.

articles.title: Cosby Trial Is a Big Deal in a Small Town, but Hardly a Media Circus
articles.content: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — The coffee was just about pouring itself on Monday at the Sessano Cafe here, across the street from the Montgomery County Courthouse, where one of the most high-profile celebrity trials in decades is taking place. Pot after pot emptied — five times the usual amount — as television crews jockeyed to position their trucks outside.

articles.title: Want to Buy a Home? Beware: It’s a Seller’s Market
articles.content: A tight supply of houses for sale, along with rising prices and worries about higher mortgage rates, is making buying a home a challenge in some areas this season.

articles.title: Pandora, Faded Star of Online Music, Gets Cash Infusion From Sirius XM
articles.content: Pandora was early to the online music business, introducing a free internet radio service just a few years after Apple started iTunes and enjoying a successful debut as a public company.

articles.title: The Cost of Dining With Warren Buffett? This Year, It’s $2,679,001
articles.content: A bidder on eBay offered nearly $2.7 million to have lunch with the billionaire investor Warren Buffett, as part of an annual auction to benefit a nonprofit organization in San Francisco.

articles.title: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: More Ugly News for Uber
articles.content: Farhad: Hello, Mike! Usually we start off with some kind of dad joke but today there’s no time. We have a huge tech story to get to, one that will deeply affect my life and the lives of all of our readers: Taylor Swift is finally putting all of her music back on all streaming services, including Spotify. Hurrah!

articles.title: Las Vegas Man Accused of Death Threats to Lawyers Suing Fox News
articles.content: A computer repairman from Las Vegas was charged on Friday in Manhattan with threatening to kill New York lawyers who have filed an anti-discrimination suit on behalf of 11 black employees at Fox News, the police and prosecutors said.

articles.title: Opioid Dealers Embrace the Dark Web to Send Deadly Drugs by Mail
articles.content: As the nation’s opioid crisis worsens, the authorities are confronting a resurgent, unruly player in the illicit trade of the deadly drugs, one that threatens to be even more formidable than the cartels.

articles.title: Settlements for Company Sins Can No Longer Aid Other Projects, Sessions Says
articles.content: When companies settle claims of wrongdoing, they are often compelled to pay for environmental or community development projects as well as pay fines and direct compensation to victims. Sometimes the third-party payments are only marginally related to the damages caused by the company’s actions.

articles.title: Comey’s Testimony Was Ratings Gold, Even at 10 A.M.
articles.content: It was the testimony of a once-obscure former law enforcement official. Before the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. At 10 in the morning. On a workday.

articles.title: Exxon Mobil Calls Emissions Inquiry a ‘Political Witch Hunt’
articles.content: Exxon Mobil, in a court filing on Friday, accused the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, of “abuse of the powers of his office” in his investigation of the oil company.

articles.title: Former Amazon Warehouse Manager Sues for Overtime Wages
articles.content: SEATTLE — Amazon’s warehouses have a reputation as often grueling environments for the workers who pick, pack and load orders there. Managers are pushed hard, too, according to the plaintiff in a new lawsuit against the internet retailer.

articles.title: Flexibility That A.C.A. Lent to Work Force Is Threatened by G.O.P. Plan
articles.content: In recent years, millions of middle- and working-class Americans have moved from job to job, some staying with one company for shorter stints or shifting careers midstream.

articles.title: 5 Things to Consider Before Buying Today’s Hot Investment
articles.content: We are again nearing what appear to be all-time highs in the stock market, and when that happens, people tend to say and do strange things. This time around, Amazon, Apple, Google (in the form of its parent company, Alphabet), Microsoft and Netflix are worth $2.4 trillion all on their own, accounting for 13 percent of the entire American economy.

articles.title: Uber Weighs Leave of Absence for Chief Executive
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facing accusations that Uber executives turned a blind eye to sexual harassment and other corporate misbehavior, the ride-hailing service’s board moved on Sunday to shake up the company’s leadership, ahead of the release this week of an investigation’s findings on its troubled culture.

articles.title: Toasting the Ad Industry and a Book Predicting Its Doom
articles.content: New York media types aren’t quick to pass up a party, even one celebrating a book that predicts their demise.

articles.title: In Watergate, One Set of Facts. In Trump Era, Take Your Pick.

articles.title: Allied Irish Banks Could Be Valued at $14.9 Billion in I.P.O.
articles.content: LONDON — The Irish government on Monday announced a price range for Allied Irish Banks that could value the bank as high as $14.9 billion when it goes public this month — seven years after it was nationalized.

articles.title: With C.E.O. Change, G.E. Will Seek Out More Growth Overseas
articles.content: General Electric has seen the future: It is both stateless and globalist. With the anointment of John Flannery to succeed Jeffrey R. Immelt as chief executive, the $255 billion industrial titan appears to be doubling down on a strategy that transcends its American roots. Mr. Flannery has spent much of his career engineering growth abroad. He is also no stranger to restructuring.

articles.title: Ivanka Trump Brand Ended Deal With Japanese Firm Over Government Ties
articles.content: Ivanka Trump’s fashion brand called off a deal with a major Japanese apparel company after learning that it was backed by the Japanese government, Ms. Trump’s company said in a letter made public on Monday.

articles.title: Fujifilm-Xerox Venture Ousts Executives Over Accounting Trouble
articles.content: TOKYO — Fuji Xerox, the Japan-based joint venture between Xerox and Fujifilm Holdings, said on Monday that its chairman and three other executives were stepping down over accounting problems discovered at its operations in Australia and New Zealand.

articles.content: The laws of gravity apparently apply to technology stocks after all.

articles.title: Daily Report: Another Week of Uber News

articles.title: A Top Uber Executive Departs, Fraying the Company’s ‘A-Team’

articles.content: BEIJING — President Trump is poised to add six new trademarks to his expanding portfolio in China, in sectors including veterinary services and construction, potentially renewing concerns about his possible conflicts of interest.

articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Goodbye, Yahoo. Hello, Oath.

articles.title: Why Boutique Hotels Are So Big in Not-So-Big Cities

articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, which holds more bonds than any other investor, is planning how to shed some of them starting this year. And no one is too worried about it.

articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — David Bonderman, an Uber board member and partner at private equity firm TPG, resigned from the board of the ride-hailing company after he made a disparaging remark about women at an Uber meeting on Tuesday.

articles.title: A President at War With His Fed Chief, 5 Decades Before Trump

articles.title: Ex-Traders in Britain to Face Currency-Rigging Charges in U.S.
articles.content: LONDON — Three former traders in Britain have agreed to travel to the United States to face criminal charges that they were part of a conspiracy to rig foreign currency markets.

articles.title: C.E.O.s Say They’re Confident, but Merger Numbers Don’t Lie
articles.content: For the past several months, ever since the election, chief executives of the nation’s largest companies have repeatedly professed to be more confident than ever. They say, in survey after survey, that they are more optimistic about the economy and their own businesses, waxing about the prospect of lower regulations and lower taxes under President Trump and a Republican-controlled Congress. Investors, at the same time, have bid up the stock market.

articles.title: Taking Charge of the Battery Icon
articles.content: Q. Is there a way to always show the battery-life indicator in the Windows 10 taskbar?

articles.title: Fox News Drops ‘Fair and Balanced’ Motto
articles.content: Fox News is “Fair and Balanced” no more.

articles.title: Fed Actions Show Confidence but Are Not at Trump Speed
articles.content: WASHINGTON — As one of the longest economic expansions in American history chugs into its ninth year, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday it was raising its benchmark interest rate to a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent.

articles.title: Daily Report: The Perils of Continuing to Use Uber
articles.content: Uber has promised to reform its corporate misbehavior. On Tuesday, the company released a long list of recommendations that it plans to adopt to avoid the workplace scandals that have recently plagued it. Uber’s chief executive, Travis Kalanick, also said he planned to take a leave of absence.

articles.title: J. Crew Debt Maneuver Can Be a Model for Other Troubled Retailers
articles.content: J. Crew may have found a clever way to mend several tears in its corporate fabric. The flailing clothier owned by TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners is trying to restructure some $567 million of notes by offering holders a deal that runs the risk of irking another set of creditors. So J. Crew has stitched something up for them, too. If it manages to thread the needle, J. Crew may provide a blueprint for other wobbly retailers contemplating bankruptcy.

articles.title: Charles P. Thacker Dies at 74; Helped Design Early Personal Computer
articles.content: Charles P. Thacker, an electrical engineer who played an early, central role in some of the most important ideas in personal computing and computer networking, died on Monday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 74.

articles.title: Instant Pot, the Latest Prized Kitchen Gadget, Has Staying Power
articles.content: I’m a sucker for the latest kitchen technology. Vegetable spiralizers, smoke guns, you name it, especially if it has an LED light. And sometimes there are truly useful ones. I asked Lesley Stockton, staff writer for The Wirecutter and Sweethome, The New York Times’s product testing sites, for advice on a latest craze: the Instant Pot, a combination slow cooker/pressure cooker.

articles.title: Why Don’t You Donate for Syrian Refugees? Blame Bad Marketing
articles.content: This summer, as you’re watching television or sifting through mail, you’re likely to come across charities asking for your money. And at some point, you’ll probably dig into your pocket to help victims of last year’s Ecuadorean earthquake, the continuing drought in Yemen or some other worthy cause.

articles.title: Wells Fargo Is Accused of Making Improper Changes to Mortgages

articles.title: Using Android to Zoom In for a Closer Look
articles.content: Q. I read your recent answer to a question regarding the magnifier on iPhones. I’m visually impaired, and this helps me and many others, but I have an Android smartphone and tablet. I cannot afford Apple, so what magnifying options are available for Android?

articles.title: Oops, Wells Fargo Did It Again
articles.content: Wells Fargo, the $270 billion California-based lender, is driving its stagecoach further into the mud. It is facing several lawsuits claiming that it changed bankrupt borrowers’ mortgage terms without consent even as its fake-accounts scandal unfolded, The New York Times reported on Wednesday. The bank now run by Timothy J. Sloan is still struggling to get the basics right.

articles.title: Uber Is Sued by Woman Who Was Raped by One of Its Drivers in India

articles.title: Trump Move on Job Training Brings ‘Skills Gap’ Debate to the Fore
articles.content: President Trump is taking one of the most concrete steps of his presidency on Thursday to address the employment prospects of workers left behind by the current economic expansion. In doing so, he also joins a long-running and occasionally contentious debate over whether those workers have the skills they need to land desirable jobs.

articles.title: The Universal Phenomenon of Men Interrupting Women

articles.title: Daily Report: The Limits of A.I.

articles.title: World Offers Cautionary Tale for Trump’s Infrastructure Plan

articles.content: Hey, did you hear the one about organic drones?

articles.title: F.B.I. Botched Evidence Collection in Fraud Case, Judge Rules

articles.title: Consumer Groups Take Aim at Navient for Phone Harassment
articles.content: A half-dozen consumer groups have asked the federal government to take action against Navient, a student loan servicer, and have accused the company of “harassing and abusing” borrowers with repeated automated telephone calls, even after being asked to stop.

articles.title: Whole Foods Deal Shows Amazon’s Prodigious Tolerance for Risk
articles.content: Joke all you want about drone-delivered kale and arugula. Amazon’s $13.4 billion bet to take on the $800 billion grocery business in the United States by acquiring Whole Foods fits perfectly into the retailer’s business model.

articles.title: Farhad’s, Mike’s and Cade’s Week in Tech: More Uber, With a Dash of Amazon
articles.content: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. This week, Farhad and Mike also talked with Cade Metz, who just joined The Times as a technology reporter.

articles.title: In Whole Foods, Bezos Gets a Sustainably Sourced Guinea Pig

articles.title: Rooted in Counterculture, Whole Foods’ Founder Finds an Unlikely Refuge

He personally oversaw each step of its national expansion. During a takeover battle 10 years ago, Mr. Mackey used a pseudonym to write anonymous blog posts attacking a competitor.

articles.title: Some Global Investors See Fresh Worries in an Old Problem: China
articles.content: BEIJING — While investors have been preoccupied with President Trump and chaos in Washington, nerve-rattling elections in Europe and the uncertainty created by Federal Reserve policy and Britain’s decision to leave the European Union, a once-familiar — and possibly bigger — risk to global markets has been bubbling in the background.

articles.title: The Car Was Repossessed, but the Debt Remains

articles.title: Before You Pay for Financial Advice, Read This Guide

articles.title: Univision’s Urgent Sense of Purpose: A Newsroom and a Lifeline

The “deportation force” President Trump promised during the campaign had finally arrived, it seemed.

articles.title: Smaller Brewers Relied on RateBeer.com. Now Bud’s Maker Owns a Stake.
articles.content: From the rooftop patio of his growing brewery in the southwestern elbow of Brooklyn, Shane C. Welch, the founder and “chief visionary” of Sixpoint Brewery, appeared to have staked a nice corner of an intensely competitive beer market.

articles.title: Kushner Is Said to Be Reconsidering His Legal Team

articles.title: For the Business Traveler Worried About Security: You’re Not Alone

But now, they are contending with new complications — issues like security at border crossings and the legalities of data searches of electronic devices at airports.

articles.title: Blue Apron Pursues I.P.O. as Amazon Looms Over Industry
articles.content: Even as Amazon’s $13.4 billion bid for Whole Foods threatens to shake up food retailing, Blue Apron, a New York-based meal-delivery service, is setting its sights on a stock market debut.

articles.title: U.K. to Decide on 21st Century Fox Deal for Sky by June 29
articles.content: Rupert Murdoch’s legacy as a media mogul will be tested in the coming days, with the British government set to decide next week whether 21st Century Fox should be allowed to buy the rest of Sky, the British satellite giant.

articles.title: After Terror Attacks, Britain Moves to Police the Web
articles.content: After deadly terrorist attacks and a nationwide election, Britain is once again focusing on a controversial plan: to regulate the internet.

articles.content: You can almost hear Robin Leach narrating the introduction to an episode of “Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous” by describing a luxury yacht, diamond jewelry, a Picasso painting, and real estate in New York, Beverly Hills and London.

articles.title: Amazon Will Let Customers Try On Clothes Before Buying
articles.content: SEATTLE — For many people, buying clothing online is not worth the hassle of getting a pair of pants or a shirt that does not fit. Many retailers have sought to eliminate that risk by offering free returns on clothing, but now Amazon is going even further.

articles.title: Exxon Mobil Lends Its Support to a Carbon Tax Proposal
articles.content: Exxon Mobil, other oil companies and a number of other corporate giants announced on Tuesday that they are supporting a plan to tax carbon emissions that was put forth this year by a group of Republican elder statesmen.

articles.title: Fisticuffs Over the Route to a Clean-Energy Future

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Barclays Charged with Fraud
articles.content: The British Serious Fraud Office has charged Barclays and four of the bank’s former executives with conspiracy to commit fraud. The charges come after a five-year investigation into the London-based lender’s fund-raising at the height of the 2008 financial crisis.

articles.title: Conglomerates Didn’t Die. They Look Like Amazon.

articles.title: Investment Group Challenges Chicago Tribune in Effort to Buy Sun-Times
articles.content: With the future of The Chicago Sun-Times hanging in the balance, a group of investors led by the Chicago businessman Edwin Eisendrath submitted a bid for the newspaper on Monday, setting up a potential battle with the owner of The Chicago Tribune.

articles.title: What to Do When Chrome Wants to Update — but Can’t
articles.content: Q. I get a message when I open Chrome and use Gmail or Facebook every day that says that my Chrome version is out of date and that I need to upgrade. When I go to Chrome to check the version, it says I have the latest one. Why do I keep getting these messages?

articles.title: Ford Chooses China, Not Mexico, to Build Its New Focus
articles.content: DETROIT — In a move that highlights the shifting landscape of global auto production, Ford Motor said Tuesday that it would build its next-generation small car in China rather than in the United States or Mexico.

articles.title: ‘Is There a Man I Can Talk To?’: Stories of Sexism in the Workplace
articles.content: Last week, after an Uber board member’s wisecrack and the interruption of Senator Kamala Harris during a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing, The New York Times asked women to share their own experiences. More than 1,000 responded, offering up vivid anecdotes of times they had been interrupted, penalized for speaking up, belittled or discriminated against in terms of salary, promotions or pregnancy.

articles.title: As Travel Industry Awaits Slowdown, Travelers Pack Bags — for Now
articles.content: The travel industry is voicing a common refrain: President Trump’s travel ban, terror attacks in Europe and a laptop ban represent a recipe for a potential sharp decline in visitors to and from the United States.

articles.title: George Clooney’s Tequila Company Sold for Up to $1 Billion
articles.content: George Clooney is an award-winning actor, a new father and a world-class prankster.

articles.title: Former Enron Prosecutor Leslie Caldwell to Join Latham & Watkins
articles.content: Leslie R. Caldwell, who pushed a tougher approach against executive wrongdoing while head of the Justice Department’s criminal division, is joining the law firm Latham & Watkins. She will become a partner in the firm’s white-collar defense and investigations practice in September, working in its San Francisco office.

articles.title: Daily Report: The Power of Social Media in Holding Brands to Acccount
articles.content: Behold the power of social media in holding brands to account. For many of us, that has become the most effective political action we can take.

articles.title: Raw Nostalgia: Cookie Dough Is the Latest Dessert Trend
articles.content: The line for Dō, a sweet shop in Greenwich Village, wound halfway down the block on a recent Thursday evening. Inside, employees wearing T-shirts emblazoned with the words “eat dessert first” offered tastes of flavors like chocolate chip, chocolate dream and salty-and-sweet to customers — college students and young professionals — who just could not make up their minds.

articles.title: Toshiba Picks Preferred Bidder for Microchip Business
articles.content: HONG KONG — As Toshiba, the embattled technology giant, battles for survival, it has turned to a group led by the Japanese government to buy its prized microchip business, although its plans still face a legal challenge by an American business partner.

articles.title: Uber Founder Travis Kalanick Resigns as C.E.O.
articles.content: Travis Kalanick stepped down Tuesday as chief executive of Uber, the ride-hailing service that he helped found in 2009 and built into a transportation colossus, after a shareholder revolt made it untenable for him to stay on at the company.

articles.title: Uber’s Growing Pains (and Possible Remedy)
articles.content: The list of what ails Uber is long — and has grown longer in lock step with the tenure of its founder, Travis Kalanick. His departure as chief executive amid pressure from other shareholders ends the first leg of Uber’s journey from a start-up to a $70 billion enterprise to, eventually, a public company. That it was able to jettison its controlling shareholder suggests a small, but welcome, modicum of market discipline in the start-up world.

articles.title: Too Hot to Fly? Climate Change May Take a Toll on Air Travel
articles.content: In recent days, American Airlines has been forced to cancel more than 40 flights in Phoenix. The reason: With daytime highs hovering around 120 degrees, it was simply too hot for some smaller jets to take off. Hotter air is thinner air, which makes it more difficult — and sometimes impossible — for planes to generate enough lift.

articles.title: Traveling Internationally With (or Without) a Laptop
articles.content: Q. We leave in July for two months in Europe. I can live with only an iPad, but my husband works as a consultant even when we’re overseas. He is a bit uneasy about taking his computer, but also uneasy about not taking it because of a potential laptop ban. Should we be concerned?

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Travis Kalanick Resigns as Uber Chief
articles.content: The storm of scandals surrounding Uber has finally claimed Travis Kalanick’s job atop the ride-hailing giant.

articles.title: An Index-Fund Evangelist Is Straying From His Gospel
articles.content: In his classic 1973 book “A Random Walk Down Wall Street,” Burton Malkiel, a Princeton economics professor, made an assertion that was startling at the time: that “a blindfolded monkey throwing darts at the stock listings could select a portfolio that would do just as well as one selected by the experts.”

articles.title: Tough Task for Next Uber Leader: Mending Fences With Drivers
articles.content: The huge, headline-grabbing news out of Uber this week was the resignation of its chief executive, Travis Kalanick, under pressure from the company’s board, a stunning move that capped a monthslong crisis involving sexual harassment, executive misbehavior and Uber’s hard-nosed culture.

articles.title: Virtual Reality Is a Disappointment? Not in the World of Video Gamers
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Before the end of this year, people will be able to play the popular open-world action game The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim in virtual reality. They will also be able to get their hands on virtual-reality versions of the first-person shooter game Doom, the post-apocalyptic game Fallout, and independent titles like Sisters, a horror game that explores virtual reality in an episodic format.

articles.title: Consumer Agency Condemns Abuses in Loan Forgiveness Program
articles.content: The government’s consumer watchdog is adding its voice to a growing chorus of warnings about problems with a federal program that permits people who take public service jobs to have their student loans forgiven after a decade.

articles.title: Warren E. Buffett Comes to the Aid of a Big Canadian Mortgage Lender
articles.content: When big financial companies have needed a rescue over the years, one man has often stood at the ready: Warren E. Buffett.

articles.title: Uncle Sam Wants Your Deep Neural Networks
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The Department of Homeland Security is turning to data scientists to improve screening techniques at airports.

articles.title: Shares Plunge as China Voices Concern Over ‘Systemic Risks’
articles.content: BEIJING — Some of China’s largest companies may pose a systemic risk to the country’s banks, a senior banking official said on Thursday, in the latest signal that Beijing is ratcheting up scrutiny of a financial system plagued with hidden debt that poses a hazard to the health of the economy.

articles.title: Inside Travis Kalanick’s Resignation as Uber’s C.E.O.
articles.content: Travis Kalanick’s final hours as Uber’s chief executive played out in a private room in a downtown Chicago hotel on Tuesday.

articles.title: ‘Nobody Is Perfect’: Some Uber Employees Balk at Travis Kalanick’s Exit
articles.content: Uber and its investors are facing a backlash over Travis Kalanick’s departure as chief executive — particularly from employees.

articles.title: Tesla in Talks to Set Up Electric Car Factory in Shanghai
articles.content: HONG KONG — Tesla Motors is in discussions to establish a factory in Shanghai, its first in China, a move that could bolster its efforts in one of its major markets even as it further lifts China’s position as a builder of electric cars.

articles.title: Outside Collectors for I.R.S. Are Accused of Illegal Practices
articles.content: Raid your 401(k). Ask your boss for a loan, load up on your credit cards, or put up your house as collateral by taking out a second mortgage.

articles.title: A Restructuring Deal That Helps Investors, Not Puerto Rico
articles.content: While it’s not clear if there are sharks in the waters surrounding Puerto Rico, the island does have sharks of a different kind — ones that hail from mainland hedge funds, municipal bond funds and insurance companies that insure against bond defaults.

articles.title: E.C.B. Seeks Control Over London Trading After ‘Brexit’
articles.content: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank took steps Friday to ensure it can oversee trillions of euros in London trading of derivatives and other risky securities even after Britain leaves the European Union.

articles.title: Google Will No Longer Scan Gmail for Ad Targeting
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Google plans to abandon its longstanding practice of scanning user email in its Gmail service to serve targeted advertising.

articles.title: Food & Wine Magazine Will Leave New York for Alabama
articles.content: Food & Wine, the glossy, chef-focused food magazine, is moving to Birmingham, Ala., joining a stable of other publications owned by Time Inc. that includes Cooking Light and Southern Living.

articles.title: Allied Irish Banks Valued at $13.3 Billion in I.P.O.
articles.content: LONDON — Nearly seven years after its collapse almost brought down Ireland’s banking system and forced the government to bail it out, one of the country’s biggest lenders returned to the public markets on Friday with a healthy valuation of $13.3 billion.

articles.title: Tips for Adding a Teenage Driver to Your Auto Insurance
articles.content: The financial shock of adding a teenager to a family auto insurance policy is getting less shocking — at least somewhat.

articles.title: A Trump Bump for Law Firm of President’s Lawyer
articles.content: Being the longtime lawyer to the man who is president of the United States can have an unexpected dividend, according to a newly released ranking of the nation’s law firms.

articles.title: Does God Want You to Spend $300,000 for College?
articles.content: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — In the remarks he prepared for his parting address to the University of Notre Dame class of 2017, Rev. John I. Jenkins urged the graduating seniors to turn and applaud their families.

articles.title: Daily Report: A Crusader Against a Severe, Previously Unseen Cyberattack
articles.content: Just when you think that cybersecurity hacking cannot grow worse, it does.

articles.title: Easiest Path to Riches on the Web? An Initial Coin Offering
articles.content: A new crop of technology entrepreneurs is forgoing the usual routes to raising money. The entrepreneurs are not pitching venture capitalists, selling stock in an initial public offering or using crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter.

articles.title: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Uber Isn’t Everything
articles.content: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

articles.title: OSHA to Roll Back Rules on Toxic Mineral at Construction Sites
articles.content: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration proposed on Friday a rollback of some Obama-era rules to protect workers in the maritime and construction industries from beryllium, a potentially deadly mineral.

articles.title: European Central Bank Moves to Wind Down Two Italian Banks
articles.content: The European Central Bank effectively euthanized two small Italian banks late Friday, in another sign that the eurozone financial system remains vulnerable even as the economy improves.

articles.title: Marion Goldin, Award-Winning ‘60 Minutes’ Producer, Dies at 76
articles.content: Marion Goldin, one of the most respected and prolific producers at CBS’s flagship newsmagazine, “60 Minutes,” died on June 15 at her home in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 76.

articles.title: E.U. Commission Approves Billions in Aid for 2 Italian Banks
articles.content: The sometimes creaky machinery of the European Union moved swiftly on Sunday to keep the struggles of two small Italian banks from undercutting confidence in the country’s fragile banking system.

articles.title: Indian Technology Workers Worry About a Job Threat: Technology
articles.content: PUNE, India — Last month, Sudhakar Choudhari took the company bus as usual from his one-bedroom apartment to the suburban offices of Tech Mahindra, a major employer of workers in India that powers the global technology machine behind the scenes. Then a manager took him into a conference room and asked him to resign.

articles.title: Third Point, a Hedge Fund, Sets Its Activist Sights on Nestlé
articles.content: LONDON — Over the past two decades, the hedge fund mogul Daniel S. Loeb has established himself as one of the biggest activist investors around. Now, he has set his sights on one of Europe’s largest corporate citizens: Nestlé, the global food giant.

articles.title: Next Stop for Preet Bharara, Fired Prosecutor? His Brother’s Media Firm
articles.content: Since Preet Bharara, the former United States attorney in Manhattan, was abruptly fired in March by President Trump, speculation has swirled about what he would do next. Would he join a white-shoe law firm, as many former prosecutors do? Would he run for office?

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 26
articles.content: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

articles.title: In Towns Already Hit by Steel Mill Closings, a New Casualty: Retail Jobs
articles.content: JOHNSTOWN, Pa. — Dawn Nasewicz comes from a family of steelworkers, with jobs that once dominated the local economy. She found her niche in retail.

articles.title: After Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis, Worries Shift to Virgin Islands
articles.content: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I. — The United States Virgin Islands is best known for its powdery beaches and turquoise bays, a constant draw for the tourists who frequent this tiny American territory.

articles.title: How a Rising Minimum Wage Affects Jobs in Seattle
articles.content: Three years ago, Seattle became one of the first jurisdictions in the nation to embrace a $15-an-hour minimum wage, to be phased in over several years.

articles.title: Effects of Takata Bankruptcy to Extend Far and Wide
articles.content: TOKYO — Takata, the airbag manufacturer at the center of the world’s largest auto safety recall, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the United States on Sunday and said it was selling its surviving operations to a rival supplier.

articles.title: A Proposed Bankruptcy for Banks That Will Lead to Bailouts
articles.content: At a time when news about Russia, health care, terrorist attacks and horrific fires dominates the headlines, it can be easy to forget that Congress continues to try to undo the regulatory reforms enacted in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis.

articles.title: Whether High Praise or Low Blow, Take It With a Grain of Salt
articles.content: When you make a habit of sharing work in the public sphere, you learn one thing fast: You’re going to get hate mail.

articles.title: Daily Report: Automation’s Effect on Developing Tech Economies
articles.content: That many workers in the United States will eventually be replaced by technology seems inevitable. The question is when — not if — it will happen. For the workers’ counterparts in India, the concerns are similar.

articles.title: At Cannes, the Great Gusher of Content Comes With Warning Signs
articles.content: CANNES, France — I imagine that covering the annual Cannes Lions advertising festival here is a little bit like covering the great Texas oil boom a century ago — only with better food, cocktails and scenery.

articles.title: European Forum Looks at Productivity, and Britain Rules on Fox’s Sky Bid
articles.content: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

articles.title: Corporate Governance Looms as an Issue for Nestlé
articles.content: Nestlé’s biggest issue is its governance.

articles.title: Jury Selection in Martin Shkreli Trial Begins With Name Calling
articles.content: More than 120 potential jurors in the fraud trial of Martin Shkreli were dismissed Monday, with some calling him “a snake,” “the most hated man in America” and “the face of corporate greed.”

articles.title: Alexa, What Happens if the Echo Has a Screen? You Get This Review
articles.content: A week ago, I began testing Amazon’s Echo Show, a new smart speaker that has a touch screen. For due diligence on the device’s capabilities, I ran it through a battery of tests, including its ability to play podcasts, book a restaurant table and list movie showtimes.

articles.title: With Crowding in U.S. Market, Activist Investors Look to Europe
articles.content: Activist investors — money managers who seek to shake up a company’s strategy in search of huge paydays — have been growing in size and power in the United States, bending the knees of even the biggest corporate titans.

articles.title: Can Good Corporate Citizenship Be Measured?
articles.content: If you spend time around corporate boardrooms these days, you’ll hear the abbreviation “E.S.G.” thrown around with such frequency it is almost a trope.

articles.title: Pearl Automation, Founded by Apple Veterans, Shuts Down
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Pearl Automation, a Silicon Valley start-up founded by former Apple employees who tried to combine Apple’s dedication to quality with a more open corporate culture, has gone out of business.

articles.title: Global Ransomware Attack: What We Know and Don’t Know
articles.content: A quickly spreading ransomware attack is hitting countries across the world including France, Russia, Spain, Ukraine and the United States, just weeks after a ransomware attack known as WannaCry.

articles.title: When Cutting Access to Health Care, There’s a Price to Pay
articles.content: Senators, the United States is a sick country.

articles.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
articles.content: $7.5 MILLION

articles.title: Google Fined Record $2.7 Billion in E.U. Antitrust Ruling
articles.content: Google suffered a major blow on Tuesday after European antitrust officials fined the search giant a record $2.7 billion for unfairly favoring some of its own services over those of rivals.

articles.title: 3 CNN Journalists Resign After Retracted Story on Trump Ally
articles.content: Three prominent journalists at CNN resigned on Monday after the cable news network was forced to retract and apologize for a story on its website involving a close ally of President Trump.

articles.title: Nestlé, Under Pressure, Plans Buyback and Perhaps Acquisitions
articles.content: LONDON — In revealing his investment position in Nestlé on Sunday, the hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb urged the company to consider slimming down, as well as buying back its stock.

articles.title: Keeping Your iPhone Out of the Drop Zone
articles.content: Q. I was adding a photo to a note on my iPhone while I was on the train and noticed I could see the names of other iPhone users listed on the screen. I assume these were people nearby. So, can they see me and isn’t this a security risk?

articles.title: So Your Dog Works as a Model? Don’t Quit Your Day Job
articles.content: Amy Peller, a marketing consultant who lives in Hoboken, N.J., was in the flagship Banana Republic store in London last winter when she looked up and recognized the model whose picture greeted her.

articles.title: ABC Settles With Meat Producer in ‘Pink Slime’ Defamation Case
articles.content: ABC reached a settlement on Wednesday with a South Dakota meat producer that accused the network of defamation following its news reports about so-called pink slime in 2012.

articles.title: Big Banks Set to Pay Out Largest Dividends in a Decade
articles.content: All of the nation’s largest banks passed the latest stress test on Wednesday, the first time all aced the exam since the Federal Reserve began administering the exercise seven years ago.

articles.title: Daily Report: Meet WannaCry’s Meaner, More Clever Sibling
articles.content: WannaCry, that cyberattack that captured tens of thousands of computers as well as the world’s attention last month, was certainly bad. Imagine one day discovering your work material or family photos are locked away by a hacker who wants you to transfer some Bitcoin in his direction to set it free.

articles.title: Blue Apron Slashes Share Price for Its I.P.O.
articles.content: When the parent of Snapchat went public in March, investors flocked to the social media upstart’s offering, eagerly pushing the money-losing company’s valuation to $34 billion.

articles.title: As Uber Stumbles, Lyft Sees an Opening, and Bites Its Tongue
articles.content: John Zimmer, the co-founder and president of Lyft, wants you to know that he is not — I repeat, not — happy about the chaos that is enveloping Uber, his fiercest rival in the ride-sharing market. There will be no corks popped at Lyft’s San Francisco headquarters over the sudden, stunning downfall of Travis Kalanick, Uber’s truculent former chief executive, and no giddy high fives will be exchanged over the chain of scandalous events that have demoralized Uber’s staff, shredded its executive ranks and damaged its reputation.

articles.title: A Costly Retraction for CNN and an Opening for Trump
articles.content: In CNN’s newsroom, it is called the Triad: a three-pronged internal system designed to ensure that sensitive reporting by the network’s journalists is unimpeachable before it runs.

articles.title: A New Kind of Tech Job Emphasizes Skills, Not a College Degree
articles.content: ROCKET CENTER, W.Va. — A few years ago, Sean Bridges lived with his mother, Linda, in Wiley Ford, W.Va. Their only income was her monthly Social Security disability check. He applied for work at Walmart and Burger King, but they were not hiring.

articles.title: Amazon’s Vision of Computing’s Future: An Information Appliance
articles.content: In the late 1970s, Jef Raskin, a pioneering technologist who was one of Apple’s earliest employees, sketched out a radical vision for the future of computing.

articles.title: Oscars Voting Pool Expands, With Female and Minority Membership Expected to Rise
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — As it races to leave behind its days as an exclusive club primarily for white men, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for the second year in a row invited hundreds of female and minority professionals to become members.

articles.title: Walgreens Calls Off Deal to Buy Rite Aid
articles.content: Walgreens Boots Alliance and Rite Aid said on Thursday that they had called off their long-planned merger after antitrust authorities indicated they were not likely to approve the combination of two of the nation’s biggest drugstore chains.

articles.title: Greta Van Susteren Leaving MSNBC After Less Than Six Months
articles.content: For the second time in less than a year, the anchor Greta Van Susteren has been abruptly let go by a cable news network.

articles.title: Why Fog Lamps Are Starting to Disappear
articles.content: Add another item to the list of once-common features — including ashtrays, spare tires and turn-the-key ignition switches — disappearing from new cars: fog lamps.

articles.title: Times Staff Members Protest Cuts and Changes to News Operation
articles.content: With the imminent elimination of a stand-alone copy desk at The New York Times, copy editors and reporters have sent two strongly worded letters to top management voicing their concerns over the changes to the newsroom’s structure.

articles.title: AMC and Comcast Try Something New: An Upgrade That Cuts Commercials
articles.content: Ratings are down and cable subscriptions are shrinking, so what are cable channels to do?

articles.title: Setback for Murdoch in $15 Billion Sky Takeover
articles.content: For years, Rupert Murdoch has tried to cement his legacy by adding Sky, the European satellite giant, to his global media empire. That quest was delayed once again Thursday as the British authorities asked regulators to further examine whether the $15 billion deal would give the Murdoch family too much control over the country’s media.

articles.title: Shkreli’s Lawyer Calls Him ‘Strange’ but Berates Fraud Case Against Him
articles.content: An odd duck. Perhaps autistic. Weird. Maybe with Asperger’s. A guy who shuffled around his office in bunny slippers with a stethoscope around his neck because he felt comfortable that way.

articles.title: Tech, Fed, Trump: So Many Reasons to Worry About the Market
articles.content: Throughout the turbulence of his first months in office, President Trump has been able to point to one bastion of support: the stock market. Earlier this month he tweeted the “great economic news” he thinks the mainstream media has been ignoring: The Dow Jones industrial average was up 16 percent and the Nasdaq up 19.5 percent since his election. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross maintained that the Trump administration had bestowed $4 trillion in gains on investors.

articles.title: Japanese Airline Apologizes After Disabled Man Crawls Aboard
articles.content: TOKYO — A Japanese airline has apologized to a disabled rights activist, who is partly paralyzed, after it tried to prevent him from boarding a flight at a remote airport, prompting him to crawl up a portable boarding staircase to reach the plane’s cabin.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Big Banks Set for Big Payouts
articles.content: The largest banks in the United States have passed the latest stress test — the first time this has happened since the Federal Reserve began the exercise seven years ago.

articles.title: Solar Trade Case, With Trump as Arbiter, Could Upend Market
articles.content: Millions of Americans now get their electricity, at least in part, from the solar panels that have rapidly spread throughout the country since 2010, thanks to their sharply declining cost. For customers — including homeowners, businesses and utilities — as well as for the companies that promote and install them, cheap solar panels have been a good thing.

articles.title: Deciding When to Use Your Own Router
articles.content: Q. If my broadband provider gives me one of those modem-router combination boxes for my service, do I have to use it or can I use my own? What are the pros and cons?

articles.title: Daily Report: In Paris, They Do Start-Ups With Style
articles.content: In Silicon Valley, people famously work long hours. Do what it takes. Perfect that gadget or widget. Help your wealthy venture capital backer raise the money necessary to buy that sweet summer villa on Capri.

articles.title: Delete Hate Speech or Pay Up, Germany Tells Social Media Companies
articles.content: BERLIN — Social media companies operating in Germany face fines of as much as $57 million if they do not delete illegal, racist or slanderous comments and posts within 24 hours under a law passed on Friday.

articles.title: Trump’s Attack on Mika Brzezinski Draws Rebukes Across a Fractious Media
articles.content: President Trump’s extraordinary attack on the television host Mika Brzezinski on Thursday capped a week of mounting acrimony between the White House and the press.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Easy Money Is Drying Up, and Markets Tremble
articles.content: It could be time for markets to come down from their sugar highs.

articles.title: ‘Morning Joe’ Hosts and Trump Bring National Enquirer Into Their Feud
articles.content: President Trump remained embroiled in a rumpus with two cable talk-show hosts on Friday, a surreal dispute featuring allegations of extortion, dueling tweets and low-rent insults that has little precedent in recent political history.

articles.title: All-Clear for Big Banks Raises Fears of a Return to Risk
articles.content: It took a decade — and $200 billion in fines — but the big banks are back.

articles.title: Women in Tech Speak Frankly on Culture of Harassment
articles.content: Their stories came out slowly, even hesitantly, at first. Then in a rush.

articles.title: Trump, Mika Brzezinski and Joe Scarborough: A Roller-Coaster Relationship
articles.content: President Trump drew widespread condemnation on Thursday for a series of early-morning tweets in which he attacked the television host Mika Brzezinski, calling her “low I.Q. Crazy Mika” and referring to a past meeting during which he claimed “she was bleeding badly from a face-lift.”
